questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of prolonged crutch use due to a leg injury presents with weakness in his hand. He reports difficulty extending his wrist and fingers and a decreased sensation on the back of his hand. These symptoms have progressively worsened over the past few weeks. Which of the following structures is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior Cord

 

  • Crutch palsy is a condition where there is a nerve injury due to the prolonged use of crutches that compresses the nerves in the axillary region.
  • In Crutch palsy, the nerve injured is the radial nerve.
  • Posterior Cord is one of the three cords of the brachial plexus.
  • It gives rise to several important nerves, including the axillary and radial nerves.
  • The radial nerve, which is most commonly affected in crutch palsy, originates from the posterior cord.
  • Therefore, while the posterior cord itself is not directly compressed in crutch palsy, its derivative (the radial nerve) is affected.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Lateral cord. 

 

  • Lateral Cord is the cord of the brachial plexus which gives rise to nerves like the musculocutaneous nerve and contributes to the median nerve.
  • The lateral cord is not typically implicated in crutch palsy. The nerves it gives rise to, are not the ones usually compressed or damaged by the use of crutches.

 

Option C) Medial cord. 

 

  • Medial Cord is the third cord of the brachial plexus and contributes to the formation of the median nerve and ulnar nerve.
  • Similar to the lateral cord, the medial cord is not directly involved in crutch palsy. The nerves originating from the medial cord are not the primary ones affected by crutch use.

 

Option D) Upper trunk.

 

  • Upper Trunk is formed by the union of the C5 and C6 nerve roots and is part of the brachial plexus.
  • It gives rise to branches that contribute to the formation of divisions of brachial plexus.
  • The upper trunk is not directly affected in crutch palsy.
  • The condition primarily involves nerve compression further down the brachial plexus, particularly the radial nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Posterior Cord is one of the three cords of the brachial plexus.
  • It gives rise to several important nerves, including the axillary and radial nerves.
  • The radial nerve, which is most commonly affected in crutch palsy, originates from the posterior cord.
  • Therefore, while the posterior cord itself is not directly compressed in crutch palsy, its derivative (the radial nerve) is affected.

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, page no. 47

questions.text: A child with loose stools for one day presented to your OPD. On examination, signs of dehydration were present and the child was given ORS. It facilitates glucose absorption through which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SGLT1

 

  • ORS contains Na+ and glucose which facilitates glucose absorption through SGLT 1 (Sodium-dependent glucose co-transporter - 1).

choices.text: Muscle glycogen phosphorylase

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents to the outpatient clinic with a swollen abdomen and failure to thrive. On examination, his liver is palpable 4 cm below the right costal margin, and he has a doll-like face with chubby cheeks. Laboratory investigations reveal fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, and hyperuricemia. A liver biopsy demonstrates increased glycogen storage with normal structure. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this patient's clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glucose-6-phosphatase

 

  • This clinical presentation is indicative of a glycogen storage disease known as Von Gierke disease, which is characterized by an enzyme deficiency affecting glucose-6-phosphatase leading to impaired glucose release from glycogen, resulting in fasting hypoglycemia.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Glucokinase. This enzyme is involved in glucose phosphorylation, mainly in the liver and pancreas, but its deficiency is not associated with the clinical features described.

 

Option B) Muscle Glycogen Phosphorylase. Deficiency in muscle glycogen phosphorylase is associated with McArdle disease, leading to exercise intolerance and muscle cramps. It is not the cause of the symptoms in this case.

 

Option D) Phosphofructokinase. Deficiency in phosphofructokinase is associated with Tarui disease, leading to exercise intolerance and myopathy. It is not the cause of the symptoms described.

 

Ref: Harper’s 30th edition, page no. 183

choices.text: Angiotensin Il inhibitor
Neutral endopeptidase inhibitor

questions.text: Sacubitril is a new drug approved for chronic heart failure. The mechanism of action of Sacubitril is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neutral endopeptidase inhibitor

 

  • Sacubitril is a Neprilysin inhibitor (Neutral Endopeptidase inhibitor).
  • Neprilysin is the enzyme that metabolizes Atrial Natriuretic Peptide, Substance P, Bradykinin, Adrenomedullin and Angiotensin II.
  • It is used in a 1:1 ratio with Valsartan (Angiotensin Receptor Blocker), thereby increasing the levels of the other substances which helps in decreasing the blood pressure in a patient of chronic heart failure.

choices.text: Invasive ductal carcinoma
Inflammatory breast cancer

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient presents with chronic eczematous changes and scaling of the skin on her nipple and areola of the left breast. She also reports occasional nipple discharge. Mammography and ultrasound reveal no underlying mass or calcifications within the breast tissue. A biopsy of the nipple and areolar skin is performed. On histopathological examination, the biopsy reveals the presence of malignant cells in the epidermis of the nipple and areola, characterized by large, pale, and atypical cells with prominent nuclei. No underlying ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) or invasive carcinoma is identified within the breast parenchyma. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient, considering the clinical presentation and histopathological findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Paget's disease

 

PAGET'S DISEASE

 

  • Paget's disease of the breast is a rare form of breast cancer that primarily affects the skin of the nipple and areola.
  • It can mimic benign skin conditions but represents underlying breast malignancy.
  • The histopathological findings of malignant cells in the epidermis of the nipple and areola without underlying DCIS or invasive carcinoma are consistent with Paget's disease of the breast.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Mondor's disease. Mondor's disease is a rare condition characterized by thrombophlebitis (inflammation of a vein with blood clot formation) of the superficial veins of the breast or chest wall. It typically presents with palpable cord-like structures beneath the skin. It is not associated with the described clinical and histopathological findings in this case.

 

Option B) Invasive ductal carcinoma. Invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer, characterized by the invasion of malignant cells into the surrounding breast tissue. It typically presents with a mass or abnormal mammographic findings, which were not seen in this case. Additionally, it often involves underlying DCIS, unlike the described histopathological findings.

 

Option C) Inflammatory breast cancer. Inflammatory breast cancer is an aggressive form of breast cancer characterized by redness, warmth, and swelling of the breast, along with skin changes and rapid progression. This condition is associated with underlying invasive breast cancer, and the clinical presentation is different from the chronic eczematous changes and scaling described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Paget's disease of the breast is a rare form of breast cancer characterized by eczematous changes, scaling, and nipple discharge.
  • The malignant cells are typically confined to the epidermis of the nipple and areola, and there may be no underlying mass or calcifications within the breast tissue.
  • It is crucial to recognize this condition because it often signifies underlying breast malignancy, which may require further evaluation and treatment.
  • Regular breast self-exams, clinical breast exams, and mammography are essential for early detection of breast abnormalities and cancers.

questions.text: Cutaneous larva migrans is most commonly caused by which organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ancylostoma braziliense

 

  • Cutaneous larva migrans is most commonly caused by Ancylostoma braziliense.
  • Cutaneous larva migrans or ground itch or creeping eruption is caused by nematode larvae that infect by skin penetration.
  • The most common cause is non-human species of Hookworm Ancylostoma braziliense and A. caninum.
  • Larva currens – Strongyloides stercolaris

choices.text: Glaister keen rod
Gleen Krag rod

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glaister keen rod

 

  • Glaister keen rods are glass or plastic rods with a diameter of 6mm.
  • They have a globe at one end.
  • It is used for close examination of the hymen for tears.
  • The rod is warmed to body temperature and passed through the hymenal orifice, spherical head first; then it is passed round the posterior surface of the hymen, which is slightly stretched by separation of labia minora.
  • In this way, edges of the hymen become slightly everted.
  • This natural notch is easily differentiated from tears, recent or old.

 

Ref: KSN Reddy, Textbook of Forensic medicine & toxicology, 33rd edition, page no. 419

questions.text: Identify the part marked in the endotracheal tube.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Murphy’s eye

 

  • The part of the endotracheal tube indicated by the arrows in the image is known as Murphy's eye.
  • This is a hole on the side of the distal end of the tube.
  • It is designed to provide an alternative pathway for airflow in case the main lumen of the tube becomes obstructed, thus ensuring continuous ventilation.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Cuff. The cuff is a balloon-like structure near the end of the tube, which is inflated to secure the tube within the trachea and prevent air from leaking around the tube.

 

Option B) Radiological Mark. This is typically a line or series of markings along the length of the tube that can be seen on an X-ray to help determine the position of the tube within the trachea.

 

Option D) Distal End. The distal end is the tip of the endotracheal tube that enters the trachea, but it is not what is being indicated by the arrows in the image.

 

  • The correct answer is Option C, Murphy’s Eye. This feature is a safety mechanism to reduce the risk of complete airway obstruction if the end of the tube becomes occluded by mucus, blood, or the tracheal wall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To identify Murphy's eye on an endotracheal tube as a secondary opening that provides an alternative path for ventilation, which is crucial if the main lumen becomes blocked.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology, 5th edition, page no. 321

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with a complaint of sudden-onset hip pain after slipping and falling on an icy sidewalk. She describes the pain as severe and localized to her right hip. On physical examination, her right leg is shortened, and there is limited range of motion with the hip held in flexion, adduction, and internal rotation. Which of the following best describes the likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior hip dislocation

 

  • A posterior hip dislocation occurs when the femoral head is forced out of the hip joint posteriorly. 
  • This commonly occurs due to trauma, such as a fall on the buttocks or a direct blow to the flexed knee. 
  • The clinical presentation described (sudden-onset severe pain, shortened leg, limited range of motion in flexion, adduction, and internal rotation) is characteristic of a posterior hip dislocation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior hip dislocation. Anterior hip dislocation is less common than posterior hip dislocation. It typically occurs when there is a force applied to the hip joint with the hip in a flexed, abducted, and externally rotated position. This would result in the hip being dislocated forward, not backward. The presentation described (shortened leg with limited range of motion in flexion, adduction, and internal rotation) is more consistent with a posterior hip dislocation.

 

Option B. Stress fracture of the femur. A stress fracture of the femur may cause hip pain, but it is not typically associated with sudden-onset severe pain and a shortened leg. Stress fractures usually develop over time due to repetitive stress on the bone and are not typically caused by a single traumatic event like a fall.

 

Option C. Osteoarthritis of the hip. Osteoarthritis of the hip is a chronic condition characterized by gradual joint degeneration. It may cause hip pain and limited range of motion, but it would not typically present with sudden-onset severe pain and a shortened leg.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Posterior hip dislocation is a medical emergency that can result from high-energy trauma, such as a fall or motor vehicle accident. 
  • It is crucial to recognize the clinical signs, including a shortened, adducted, flexed, and internally rotated leg, as well as limited hip motion. 
  • Prompt reduction of the dislocation is essential to prevent complications such as avascular necrosis of the femoral head. 
  • This case illustrates the importance of identifying and managing this condition in a timely manner to optimize patient outcomes.

choices.text: Acute Otitis Media
Ramsay Hunt Syndrome

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with acute onset of right-sided facial paralysis, severe ear pain, and a vesicular rash in his right ear. He also reports some hearing loss and vertigo on the same side. His past medical history is significant for chickenpox in childhood. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ramsay Hunt Syndrome

 

  • Ramsay Hunt Syndrome (Herpes Zoster Oticus) is caused by the reactivation of Varicella-Zoster Virus in the Geniculate Ganglion.
  • It presents with a triad of ipsilateral facial paralysis, ear pain, and a vesicular rash in the ear or oral mucosa.
  • Hearing loss and vertigo can also occur due to the involvement of the vestibulocochlear nerve.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Bell's palsy is characterized by acute onset of unilateral facial paralysis. However, it is not typically associated with a vesicular rash or other cranial nerve involvement, which is present in this case.

 

Option B) Acute otitis media can cause ear pain but is not associated with facial paralysis or a vesicular rash. It also typically presents with signs of infection like fever and a bulging tympanic membrane.

 

Option D) An Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma) can cause hearing loss and balance issues but does not typically present with facial paralysis or a vesicular rash. It is a slow-growing benign tumor on the vestibulocochlear nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective of this question is to identify Ramsay Hunt syndrome (Herpes Zoster Oticus) as a condition characterized by the combination of ipsilateral facial paralysis, ear pain, and a vesicular rash in the ear, along with possible hearing loss and vertigo, due to reactivation of the Varicella-Zoster Virus.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, page no. 52

choices.text: District TB centre
Intermediate Reference Laboratory
Designated Microscopy Centre

questions.text: Which of the options is considered the most peripheral center under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Designated Microscopy Centre

 

  • Among the given options, the most peripheral center under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme organization structure is the Designated Microscopy Centre (DMC). This remains same for the new National TB Elimination Program 2020 too.
  • The DMC is the first point of contact for patients seeking diagnosis and treatment for tuberculosis (TB) and is responsible for collecting sputum samples and conducting smear microscopy to detect the presence of TB bacteria.
  • The DMCs are established at the periphery level of the healthcare system, such as at the level of Primary Health Centers or Community Health Centers, to ensure that TB diagnosis and treatment services are accessible to people in their own communities.

 

 

  • Designated Microscopy Centre (DMC) remains most peripheral unit for the new National TB Elimination Program 2020 too.

choices.text: The surgeon must use chromic catgut.
The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures.
The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.
The surgeon must use the single layer seromuscular suture technique.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with symptoms of an inguinal hernia. During the operation, the surgeon observes a segment of necrotic bowel in the hernial sac. What is the appropriate course of action for resection and anastomosis of a necrotic bowel seen during surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.

 

  • The single-layer, extramucosal suture technique of Halstead involves using a single layer of sutures to join the two ends of the bowel together, while avoiding the mucosal layer.
  • This technique is less time-consuming than the double-layer technique and reduces the risk of complications such as bleeding, stricture formation, and anastomotic leak.
  • This is one of the preferred techniques in small bowel anastomosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) The surgeon must use chromic catgut. Chromic catgut is a type of absorbable suture that is made from the collagen found in sheep or goat intestine. Chromic catgut has a relatively short duration of tensile strength, and so it is not recommended for use in areas of high tension or stress, including intestinal anastomosis.

 

Option B) The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures. The submucosa is a layer of tissue beneath the mucosal lining of the bowel. It should be included in sutures as it is the toughest layer of the bowel.

 

Option D) The surgeon must use the single-layer seromuscular suture technique. The single-layer seromuscular suture technique involves suturing the seromuscular layer of the bowel to join the two ends together. This technique is quick and easy to perform but may not be suitable as it doesn’t include submucosa, which is the toughest layer of bowel during suturing.

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady comes with abnormal uterine bleeding. A hysterectomy was performed, and the following specimen was retrieved. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leiomyoma

 

 

  • The given image shows a large leiomyoma (Submucosal, i.e., the location of the fibroid is in the endometrial cavity).
  • Patients usually present with heavy menstrual bleeding.
  • According to their location, fibroids are classified according to FIGO classification.
  • Most common HPE features are: Whorled appearance in cross section, well circumscribed firm lesion. 
  • The most common degeneration associated with myomas is cystic degeneration.
  • Red degeneration is common during pregnancy.

 

 

FIGO Classification of Fibroids

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Endometrial carcinoma. This will show an irregular growth in the endometrial cavity as shown in the image.

 

 

Option C) Endometrial polyp. This will appear as a soft fleshy projection in the endometrial cavity as shown in the image.

 

 

Option D) Adenomyosis. This usually will be a globular enlargement of the uterus with myometrial thickening as shown below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Arachnoid villi malformation

questions.text: What is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aqueductal stenosis

 

  • Aqueductal stenosis is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly (enlargement of ventricles of the brain) in newborns.
  • It is a congenital condition where there is narrowing or obstruction of the cerebral aqueduct, a small channel that connects the third and fourth ventricles in the brain.
  • This obstruction can result in an enlargement of the ventricles, which can lead to hydrocephalus (accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid in the brain).
  • Arnold-Chiari malformation, Dandy-Walker syndrome, and arachnoid villi malformation are other conditions that can cause ventriculomegaly, but they are less common causes than aqueductal stenosis.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Arnold Chiari malformation will have downward displacement of cerebellum and brainstem. This is not the commonest cause of ventriculomegaly.

 

Option B) Dandy walker malformation will have cerebellar hypoplasia with hydrocephalus.

 

Option C) Arachnoid villi malformation is not the commonest cause.

questions.text: A patient presents with frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis. 24-hour urine volume was measured and recorded to be 7 liters. The urine osmolarity was 260 mOsm/L. ADH assay was performed and the recorded values were reported as 0.8 pg/mL. An MRI of the brain was performed and T1 weighted image indicated the absence of the bright spot. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pituitary DI

 

APPROACH TO POLYURIA

 

  • Water vs solute diuresis (first thing to know)
  • Water diuresis: DI, Primary polydipsia
  • Solute diuresis:
    • Glycosuria (Hyperglycemia, SGLT2 inhibitor use)
    • Iatrogenic hyper-osmolar agents (Hypertonic saline, Mannitol, Urea - from high-protein tube feeding, Radiocontrast agents)
    • Salt wasting (e.g., Medullary cystic disease, Diuretics, CSWS, Obstructive uropathy -especially if B/L, resolving ATN)
  • MMS algorithm for finding out the cause:

 

 

 

  • Before giving desmopressin → S. Na+ should be 145 (or) P. Osm should be > 295.
  • If this cannot be achieved (usually due to severe thirst) during water deprivation, Alternative for water deprivation is Hypertonic saline infusion to achieve S. Na > 145 or P. Osm > 295, then desmopressin test can be performed.
  • Hypertonic saline (to ↑P. Osm) + Plasma AVP measurement in response to ↑ P. Osm due to hypertonic saline.
  • Plasma AVP is unstable and needs stringent storage techniques.
  • Based on AVP levels, can diagnose pituitary vs nephrogenic vs primary polydipsia.
  • Diagnostic accuracy is questionable.

 

**Plasma Co-Peptin (analogues to C-peptide of insulin) can be used for central vs nephrogenic DI.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with motor traffic accident with BP 90/60mm Hg. On examination, he was stable with GCS 15/15. The pupil was reactive to light. Tenderness and bruising over the left lower chest wall with petechia were seen. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) eFAST

 

  • Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (eFAST) is the initial step in approach to blunt trauma abdomen, in stable and unstable patients.

choices.text: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient presents with a history of loss of interest in day-to-day activities, weight loss, insomnia, and sadness for six months. She also recalls hearing a voice once that ordered her to kill herself. What is the DSM-V diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

 

  • The patient's symptoms of loss of interest in daily activities, weight loss, insomnia, and persistent sadness align with major depressive disorder.
  • The presence of auditory hallucination (voice ordering her to commit suicide) indicates an additional psychotic feature.
  • Hence, the diagnosis would be Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Schizophrenia. It is a chronic disorder typically lasting more than 6 months, with symptoms like delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, etc. without a predominant mood episode.

 

Option C) Schizoaffective disorder. It has features of both schizophrenia and mood disorders concurrently.

 

Option D) Delusional disorder. The primary feature is a persistent delusion without other symptoms of psychosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features (also known as psychotic depression), is seen in moderate to severe depressive disorder where the individual experiences both depressive symptoms and psychosis, such as delusions or hallucinations.
  • These psychotic symptoms could be mood congruent (i.e., content of delusion/hallucination is consistent with the depressed mood) or mood incongruent.
  • Psychotic symptoms align with the mood episode's theme, differentiating it from schizoaffective disorder.
  • Treatment includes typically combining antipsychotics with antidepressants.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No. 356, 360

questions.text: Match the Genital ulcer disease in Column A with its clinical presentation in Column B.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a

 

  • The correct match between the Viral organisms/infections in Column A with its Histopathological characteristic features in Column B is:

 

 

      1.  

1. Donovanosis (Granuloma inguinale):

 

  • Presentation: b. Lymphadenopathy absent
  • Donovanosis is a bacterial infection caused by Klebsiella granulomatis.
  • It presents with beefy red ulcers that bleed easily on contact.
  • The key feature is the absence of lymphadenopathy, distinguishing it from other causes of genital ulcers.

 

  1.  

2. Chancre (Primary syphilis):

 

  • Presentation: c. Painless ulcer
  • The chancre of primary syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, is typically a single, firm, round, and painless ulcer.
  • It is the hallmark of the initial stage of syphilis.
      1.  

 

3. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV):

 

  • Presentation: a. Ulcer absent
  • LGV is a sexually transmitted infection caused by specific serovars of Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • The primary lesion may be a transient, painless ulcer or papule that often goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage is characterized by significant inguinal and/or femoral lymphadenopathy, which can be painful.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective is to match the correct clinical presentation with the genital ulcer disease.
  • Donovanosis presents with ulcers but no lymphadenopathy, chancres from syphilis are painless ulcers, and LGV often presents without an ulcer but with lymphadenopathy.
  • Understanding the clinical presentation of genital ulcer diseases is essential for correct diagnosis and treatment, which is particularly relevant for medical students preparing for residency.

 

Ref: Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no. 771; Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th Edition, page no. 30.1-30.25; Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition, Page no. 1463-1467

questions.text: When light is flashed onto one eye, both the eyes’ pupils constrict as a response. This is known as the pupillary light reflex. Where is the center for this reflex located?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Midbrain

 

  • The pupillary reflex fires are relayed to the PRETECTAL NUCLEUS located in the midbrain.
  • Afferent: Optic Nerve
  • Efferent: Short ciliary nerves

 

 

Ref: Parson’s Diseases of Eye, Page no. 34

questions.text: What are the potential consequences of an injury to the artery located under the indicated arrow?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Extradural Haemorrhage

 

  • Marked structure in the given image is pterion where four bones meet i.e, frontal bone, parietal bone, temporal bone and greater wing of sphenoid.
  • The structure that lies beneath pterion is middle meningeal vessels, rupture of which leads to extradural haemorrhage.

 

 

EXTRADURAL HEMORRHAGE (EPIDURAL HEMORRHAGE)

 

  • This hemorrhage occurs between the dura mater and the skull.
  • It's often caused by trauma leading to a tear in an artery, most commonly the middle meningeal artery.
  • This type of hemorrhage is characterized by a biconvex shape on imaging and can cause a lucid interval followed by rapid deterioration.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Subarachnoid Hemorrhage occurs between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater, usually due to the rupture of cerebral aneurysms. The blood spreads over the surface of the brain, often leading to a sudden and severe headache.

 

Option C) Subdural Hemorrhage occurs beneath the dura mater, above the arachnoid layer of the meninges, usually due to tearing of the bridging veins. It is more associated with venous bleeding and chronic in nature, especially in the elderly and in alcoholics.

 

Option D) Intraparenchymal Hemorrhage refers to hemorrhage directly into the brain tissue and can result from various causes, including hypertension, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, and trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extradural Hemorrhage (Epidural Hemorrhage):

 

  • This hemorrhage occurs between the dura mater and the skull.
  • It's often caused by trauma leading to a tear in an artery, most commonly the middle meningeal artery.
  • This type of hemorrhage is characterized by a biconvex shape on imaging and can cause a lucid interval followed by rapid deterioration.

 

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Clinical Neuroanatomy, 2nd edition, page no. 183, 188

questions.text: Which of the following is most potent stimulators of aldosterone secretion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyperkalemia

 

  • Hyperkalemia and activation of renin-angiotensin system are the most potent stimulators of aldosterone secretion.
  • Aldosterone, secreted by the zona glomerulosa cells of the adrenal cortex, is an important regulator of sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion by the renal tubules.
  • The primary site of aldosterone action is on the principal cells of the cortical collecting tubule.
  • Aldosterone increases sodium reabsorption while at the same time increasing potassium secretion is by stimulating the sodium-potassium ATPase pump on the basolateral side of the cortical collecting tubule membrane.
  • Aldosterone also increases the sodium permeability of the luminal side of the membrane.
  • Minimal levels of aldosterone not affect sodium balance but greatly impairs the regulation of renal potassium excretion and potassium concentration of the body fluids.
  • Thus, aldosterone is even more important as a regulator of potassium concentration than it is for sodium concentration.

choices.text: NADPH production by the hexose monophosphate shunt is decreased.
Acetoacetate is the major fuel for muscle.
Glucose transport into adipose tissue is decreased.
The major fuel used by the brain is glucose.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true in the well-fed state?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The major fuel used by the brain is glucose.

 

  • Glucose is the major fuel for the brain in the well-fed state and requires a continuous supply of it.
  • During starvation or fasting, the brain obtains approximately 75% of its energy from circulating ketone bodies. 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) NADPH production by the hexose monophosphate shunt is decreased. False. Liver production of NADPH is at a high level because it is needed for fatty acid synthesis.

 

Option B) Acetoacetate is the major fuel for muscle. False. During the absorptive phase, ketone bodies such as acetoacetate and 3-hydroxybutyrate are low (with glucose rather than these ketones used by muscle.

 

Option C) Glucose transport into adipose tissue is decreased. False. Glucose is actively transported into all cells, including adipocytes, which require it to form glycerol-3-phosphate for esterification of fatty acids into triacylglycerides.

 

Ref: Vasudevan, 9th edition, page no. 101

questions.text: Corticosteroid indicated for the stimulation of fetal lung maturation in preterm labor is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Betamethasone

 

  • Corticosteroids are used in pregnant females delivering premature babies in order to prevent Respiratory Distress Syndrome in the newborn due to inadequate levels of surfactants in the lungs of premature babies.
  • Corticosteroids also reduce the chances of development of Necrotizing Enterocolitis and Intraventricular Hemorrhage in the newborn.
  • For this purpose, we can use either Dexamethasone or Betamethasone.
  • Dose:
    1. Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly x 4 doses
    2. Betamethasone 12mg 24 hourly x 2 doses
  • Total dose should be 24 mg in 48 hrs.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, jaundice, and fatigue. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin levels. Imaging studies show a dilated common bile duct with a distal obstruction. A biopsy of the obstructed region is performed. Histopathological Examination shows cuboidal to columnar epithelial cells lining the bile ducts. Immunohistochemical staining reveals the presence of a cytokeratin, that is commonly expressed in simple epithelial tissues. Based on the histopathological findings and immunohistochemical staining results, which cytokeratin is most likely to be expressed in the epithelial cells of the bile ducts in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CK-8

 

  • CK-8 is expressed in various simple epithelial tissues, and it is a marker commonly used for identifying such cells.
  • In the context of the scenario, where the immunohistochemical staining reveals the presence of a cytokeratin commonly expressed in simple epithelial tissues and the histopathological examination shows cuboidal to columnar epithelial cells lining the bile ducts, CK-8 is the most appropriate cytokeratin marker for this situation.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) CK-19. CK-19 is commonly expressed in the biliary epithelial cells and is often used as a marker for hepatobiliary structures. However, in the context of the scenario, the presence of cuboidal to columnar epithelial cells lining the bile ducts suggests a biliary origin. While CK-19 is expressed in biliary epithelium, CK-7 is often a more specific marker for these cells.

 

Option B) CK-7. CK-7 is typically expressed in the epithelial cells of various organs, including the biliary system. CK-7 could be a reasonable consideration, and it is commonly used as a marker for biliary epithelium. However, in this case, the scenario specifically mentions that the cytokeratin detected is commonly expressed in simple epithelial tissues, which makes CK-8 (Option C) a more fitting choice.

 

Option D) CK-20. CK-20 is typically expressed in the epithelial cells of the gastrointestinal tract and is not commonly associated with biliary epithelium. Using CK-20 to identify bile duct epithelium in this context is not appropriate, especially in the presence of obstructive jaundice and a distal obstruction in the common bile duct.

questions.text: A patient presents with gastrointestinal problems including abdominal pain and distension, bloody and mucus-filled diarrhea, and tenesmus, with rectal prolapse. A stool examination reveals the presence of typical barrel-shaped eggs. What is the possible causative agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trichuris trichiura

 

  • The given clinical picture and the barrel-shaped eggs are suggestive of infection with Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).
  • The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:
    • Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
    • They float in the saturated salt solution.
    • It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.
  • Table listing appearance of various organism in stool/sputum examination:

choices.text: Only in lower limbs
In hands and feet in a glove and stocking pattern
On the dorsal aspect of the body, except back of chest and buttocks
Over face, neck, front of upper part of chest, upper and lower limbs

questions.text: A person in a village sees a dead body floating in a nearby pond. He informs the police and the dead body is brought for postmortem examination. What is the likely place where postmortem staining will be seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Over face, neck, front of upper part of chest, upper and lower limbs

 

CORE CONCEPT

 

  • Postmortem hypostasis occurs in dependent parts.
  • In drowning, the body floats with face down, buttocks up, legs and arms hanging down in front of the body as shown below:

 

 

  • Hence, in drowning, the postmortem staining occurs over face, neck, front of upper part of chest, upper and lower limbs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Only in lower limbs is incorrect as explained above.

 

Option B) In hands and feet in a glove and stocking pattern. This occurs in hanging as hands and feet become dependent parts in a suspended body. The staining develops in the lower region of lower limbs and upper limbs (hands/forearms) — glove and stocking PM staining.

 

Option C) On the dorsal aspect of the body, except back of chest and buttocks. This will be seen if the body is lying in supine position. In this position, the staining will be absent on back of chest and buttocks as these are pressure points.

 

Ref: Synopsis of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 28th edition, Page no. 89

questions.text: A patient was operated for resection of left upper lobe of the lung. 2 hours after the surgery, his vitals were BP = 70/50 mm of Hg, HR = 136 bpm, SPO2 = 92 and surgical drain was filled with blood. Immediate re-exploration was planned. IV anaesthetic agent of choice is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ketamine

 

  • Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic that has the unique property of providing sedation while maintaining cardiovascular stability.
  • It does this by stimulating the sympathetic nervous system and inhibiting the reuptake of norepinephrine, which can increase arterial pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output.
  • This makes it an excellent choice for patients who are hemodynamically unstable, as in the case described.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Propofol. Propofol is a commonly used IV anaesthetic agent known for its rapid onset and short duration of action. However, it causes vasodilation and myocardial depression, which can lead to hypotension. Therefore, it is not the ideal choice for a patient who is already in a state of shock with low blood pressure.

 

Option C) Thiopentone. Thiopentone is a barbiturate that is also used for inducing anesthesia. Like propofol, it can cause cardiovascular depression leading to hypotension, which would not be beneficial in a patient who is already hypotensive following surgery.

 

Option D) Etomidate. Etomidate is known for its cardiovascular stability and is often used in patients at risk of hypotension. However, it does not provide any sympathetic stimulation and may not be as effective as ketamine in supporting the cardiovascular system in a shock state.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ketamine is the anaesthetic of choice in patients with severe hypotension and shock, due to its sympathetic stimulatory effects which help maintain arterial pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Anesthesiology, 7th edition, page no. 332-338

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents to the orthopedic clinic with a complaint of chronic knee pain and reduced mobility in his right knee. He describes the pain as aching which worsens when he tries to climb stairs or stand for extended periods. The pain has been progressively getting worse over the past few years. On physical examination, there is tenderness over the joint line, and the patient exhibits a mild antalgic gait. An X-ray of the right knee is obtained, which shows joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, subchondral sclerosis, and the presence of subchondral cysts. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the X-ray findings in this patient's knee?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Osteoarthritis

 

  • Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the gradual breakdown of cartilage and the formation of bony outgrowths (osteophytes) around the joint.
  • It is a common condition in older adults and is associated with chronic joint pain and stiffness.
  • Recognizing the typical X-ray features of osteoarthritis, including joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, subchondral sclerosis, and subchondral cysts, is crucial for diagnosing and managing this condition effectively.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disease that primarily affects synovial joints. It typically presents with symmetrical joint involvement and inflammatory changes seen on X-rays, such as joint erosions and periarticular soft tissue swelling. The clinical and radiographic features in this case do not align with rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option B) Gouty arthritis. Gouty arthritis results from the deposition of urate crystals in joints, leading to sudden and painful episodes of inflammation. It often involves the big toe joint initially and can be associated with tophi (accumulations of urate crystals). The X-ray findings described in the case are not characteristic of gout.

 

Option D) Septic arthritis. Septic arthritis is caused by a bacterial infection within a joint and presents with acute onset of joint pain, swelling, warmth, and systemic signs of infection (fever). X-rays may show joint effusion but do not typically demonstrate the specific findings mentioned in the case, such as joint space narrowing and osteophyte formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • X-ray findings in osteoarthritis often include joint space narrowing, osteophyte (bone spur) formation, subchondral sclerosis (hardening of the bone beneath the cartilage), and occasionally the presence of subchondral cysts.
  • Recognizing these radiographic features is essential for diagnosing and managing osteoarthritis effectively.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles primarily functions as a depressor of the larynx during swallowing and speaking?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sternothyroid

 

  • The sternothyroid muscle is responsible for depressing the larynx during both swallowing and speaking.
  • During swallowing, it contracts to lower the larynx, helping to protect the airway from aspiration of food or liquids into the trachea.
  • During speaking, it aids in lowering the larynx, which can be important for generating deeper vocal sounds.
  • Other depressors of larynx include sternohyoid and omohyoid muscles.

 

 

Sternothyroid

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Thyroarytenoid primarily functions as a muscle involved in adducting and adjusting the tension of the vocal cords during phonation (speaking and singing). It does not primarily act as a depressor of the larynx.

 

Option B) Cricothyroid is mainly responsible for adjusting the tension of the vocal cords, allowing for changes in pitch during phonation. It does not have a primary role as a depressor of the larynx.

 

Option C) Stylopharyngeus is involved in elevating the larynx during swallowing and speaking and is not primarily responsible for depressing the larynx.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary muscle responsible for depressing the larynx during swallowing and speaking is the sternothyroid muscle.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, page no. 283, 284

questions.text: Which article in the Indian Constitution grants the Right to Life to the individuals of India?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Article 21

 

  • The Right to Life is given in Article 21 of the Indian Constitution.
  • The Article 21 states that “No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to a procedure established by law.”
  • Thus, article 21 secures two rights:
    1. Right to life
    2. Right to personal liberty

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Article 11 defines the right of the parliament to regulate the right of citizenship by law.

 

Option C) Article 23 defines the prohibition of traffic in human beings and forced labor.

 

Option D) Article 25 defines the freedom of conscience and free profession, practice, and propagation of religion.

questions.text: Mr. AB recently underwent surgery to remove a parathyroid gland due to hyperparathyroidism. The surgeon informed the patient that one or more of the parathyroid glands may be transferred to another location during the surgery to protect them or due to their location. The parathyroid is commonly transferred to:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Brachioradialis

 

  • The most common site for relocation of the parathyroid gland(s) is in the forearm muscle (non-dominant side Brachioradialis).
  • Transplantation to this location provides several advantages.
  • One key advantage is that it is easy to access if future surgical interventions are necessary.
  • Moreover, the forearm location allows for easy monitoring of parathyroid function using simple clinical tests.
  • The transferred gland(s) will continue to function and produce parathyroid hormone as normal in their new location, helping to regulate calcium levels in the body.
  • This also facilitates easy removal if there is disease recurrence after surgery.
  •  A total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted. This is a type of heterotopic transplant.

 

Other options:

 

Triceps, biceps and sartorius are not preferred for parathyroid transplantation.

choices.text: Testicular feminizing syndrome

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea has the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis? 

  • Normal stature
  • Thelarche – absent
  • FSH, LH – high
  • Karyotype – 46 XX
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gonadal dysgenesis

 

  • The probable diagnosis, in this case, is pure gonadal dysgenesis.
  • Whenever secondary sexual characters are ABSENT, think of ovarian or hypothalamic/pituitary causes.
  • If FSH/ LH is low – think of hypothalamic or pituitary causes (Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism)
  • If FSH/ LH is high, think of ovarian cause (hypergonadotropic hypogonadism)
    • 46 XX – gonadal dysgenesis
    • 46 XY – Swyer syndrome

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Testicular Feminization Syndrome/Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome.

 

  •  
  • 46XY
  • Uterus and ovaries absent.
  • Secondary sexual development (especially breast development present) due to peripheral production of estrogens.

 

Option C) Kallman Syndrome.

 

  •  
  • This is a cause of Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism leading to primary amenorrhoea.
  • Associated with anosmia.
  • Absent secondary sexual characters.
  • FSH and LH: Low

 

Option D) Turner Syndrome.

 

  •  
  • 45XO
  • Streak ovaries leading to low estrogen and absent secondary sexual characters.
  • FSH and LH are high.
  • Very important feature: Short stature

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Whenever secondary sexual characters are ABSENT, think of ovarian or hypothalamic/pituitary causes.
  • If FSH/ LH is low – think of hypothalamic or pituitary causes (Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism)
  • If FSH/ LH is high, think of ovarian cause (hypergonadotropic hypogonadism)
    • 46 XX – gonadal dysgenesis
    • 46 XY – Swyer syndrome

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition, Page no. 454

choices.text: Fetal left Upper limb
Fetal left lower limb
Fetal right upper limb
Fetal right lower limb

questions.text: Where would you place the pulse oximeter to measure pre-ductal oxygen saturation in an infant who was born 3 minutes ago?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fetal right upper limb

 

  • To assess preductal oxygen saturation in a newborn with patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), the recommended area to place the pulse oximeter is the right upper limb.
  • If the preductal oxygen saturation is more than 5% higher than the postductal saturation, it suggests the presence of a right-to-left shunt.
  • The best area to check postductal saturation is the foot.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Between left upper and right upper limb, we always choose right upper limb for pre ductal saturation.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy. Which investigation should be performed next to help you diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ANCA

 

  • Features are suggestive of small vessel vasculitis.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B) RA factor can be elevated in Mixed cryoglobulinemia that can have above presentations however is not very diagnostic.

 

Option C) HbsAg. Neuropathy is not common and is very rare with chronic Hepatitis B.

 

Option D) DIF is not diagnostic of small vessel vasculitis.

 

Ref: Harrison, Vasculitis syndrome, Chapter 363

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the following MRI scan.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cerebellum

 

  • The given image shows an MRI of the sagittal section of the brain.

choices.text: Affective and cognitive

questions.text: A teacher demonstrated handwashing procedures to her students. Students repeated the activity later in the day and at home. What kind of learning is going on here?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psychomotor

 

  • The scenario described involves the teacher demonstrating a physical skill (handwashing), which the students then practice and replicate.
  • This type of learning pertains to the acquisition of motor skills and involves physical movement and coordination, making it psychomotor learning.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Cognitive. It pertains to mental skills or acquiring knowledge. It involves understanding, reasoning, and thinking processes.

 

Option C) Affective. It relates to feelings, values, attitudes, motivations, and appreciations.

 

Option D) Affective and cognitive. It would involve both emotions/attitudes and mental processes, which is not the primary focus in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective: Psychomotor learning involves the acquisition and refinement of motor skills and requires physical movement and coordination. It is demonstrated in this scenario by students learning and practicing the handwashing procedure shown by their teacher.

 

Ref: Milde FK, The Function of Feedback in Psychomotor-Skill Learning, Western Journal of Nursing Research, 1988;10(4):425-434.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple tense blisters over the body associated with pruritus. On histopathology, neutrophils are visible. Which is the most likely antigen causative for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) BPAG 180

 

  • In Linear IgA Bullous Dermatosis (LABD) or Chronic Bullous Dermatosis of Childhood (CBDC), the patient's immune system mistakenly produces antibodies against BPAG 180, a protein component of hemidesmosomes in the basement membrane of the skin.

 

 

Image depicting structure of DEJ/BMZ

 

 

  • This autoimmune response leads to the characteristic tense blisters seen in LABD.
  • Neutrophils can often be seen in histopathological examinations of LABD lesions.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B) BPAG 230. This antigen is associated with Bullous Pemphigoid, not LABD.

 

Option C) Collagen 7. This antigen is related to Epidermolysis Bullosa Acquisita.

 

Option D) Desmoglein 3. It is associated with Pemphigus Vulgaris.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Identify BPAG 180 as the target antigen in LABD, which presents with tense blisters and neutrophil infiltration on histopathology.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th Edition, page no. 50.33; Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition, Page no. 323

choices.text: Primary angle closure glaucoma
Iridocorneal endothelial syndrome

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient reported with complaints of blurring of vision in his left eye for the past 2 weeks. He had a past history of central retinal vein occlusion in the left eye, which was diagnosed almost 3 months back.  Slit lamp examination revealed rubeosis iridis in all the four quadrants. The intraocular pressure (IOP) in left eye is 72 mm of Hg. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neovascular glaucoma (NVG)  

 

  • NVG has been called '90-' or '100-day glaucoma' in the past due to its typical development 3 months after the onset of CRVO.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Hypoxic retinal tissue produces angiogenic factors (like VEGF) in an attempt to revascularize hypoxic areas.
    •  The new vessels encroach on the angle and cause open angle glaucoma. Later when a neovascular membrane is formed, contraction of the membrane causes angle closure glaucoma.
  • Causes:
    • Diabetic Retinopathy (most common)
    • Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO)

 

Ref: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 8th edition, page no. 371,372

choices.text: Atrium Bulging into Aorta
Aortic Sinus Bulging into Left Atrium
Aortic Sinus Bulging into Right Atrium
Aortic Wall Tear

questions.text: What causes the appearance of the torus aorticus in the heart?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortic Sinus Bulging into Right Atrium

 

  • Torus aorticus is produced by bulging of the right posterior aortic sinus.
  • It is seen in the anterosuperior part of the interatrial septum in the right atrium.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Atrium Bulging into Aorta. Normally, there is no structural feature in which an atrium bulges into the aorta. The atria and the aorta are separate chambers with distinct functions.

 

Option B) Aortic Sinus Bulging into Left Atrium are the dilations at the root of the aorta, just above the aortic valve. While these sinuses are close to the left atrium, they do not bulge into it. The structure of the heart prevents such an occurrence under normal conditions, and such a bulging would likely indicate a pathological condition.

 

Option D) Aortic Wall Tear, also known as an aortic dissection, where the inner layer of the aorta tears, causing blood to flow between the layers of the wall of the aorta. This condition does not lead to the formation of the torus aorticus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic Sinus Bulging into Right Atrium:  

 

  • The torus aorticus is caused by the bulging of the right posterior aortic sinus into the right atrium.
  • The aortic sinus, one of the three aortic sinuses, is located near the right atrium.
  • The bulging of this sinus into the right atrium can create a noticeable impression, known as the torus aorticus, on the wall of the right atrium.

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, page no. 263

choices.text: Segment la is due to residual urine
Segment II is due to Laplace law
Micturition fails to happen in segment II
The dotted line represents that micturition has occurred

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the given cystometrogram?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Segment II is due to Laplace Law

 

  • The true statement regarding the given cystometrogram is that segment lb is due to Laplace law.
  • The law of Laplace correlates volume and wall tension, is applicable to urine storage.
  • According to Law of Laplace, the pressure (P) in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension (T) divided by the radius (R). This is expressed as P= 2T/R.
  • As the bladder gets filled, the radius increases along with the tension, hence there is a slight increase in pressure until the bladder is relatively full, which explains the flatness of the graph in segment II
  • The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL. A marked sense of fullness is felt at a bladder volume of 400ml.
  • Cystometrogram is a plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder.
  • The curve shows three segments:

 

 

  1. Initial Filling Phase (or Low-Pressure Phase): This phase represents the storage phase of bladder function.
  2. Rapid Filling Phase (or High-Pressure Phase): In this phase, the intravesical pressure increases more rapidly as the bladder volume reaches a certain threshold. The detrusor muscle, which contracts to initiate bladder emptying, starts to generate increased pressure as the bladder approaches its capacity. This phase represents the transition from storage to voiding phase.
  3. Voiding Phase (or Micturition Phase): In the voiding phase, the intravesical pressure rises to its highest level as the detrusor muscle contracts forcefully to empty the bladder. The pressure exceeds the urethral resistance, resulting in urine expulsion. This phase is associated with the sensation of needing to urinate and the act of micturition (urination).

questions.text: Rossmann fold associated NADH domain is found in which enzyme?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lactate Dehydrogenase         

                                      

OXIDOREDUCTASE GROUP OF ENZYMES WITH ROSSMAN FOLD

 

  • Lactate dehydrogenase
  • Alcohol dehydrogenase
  • Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase
  • Malate dehydrogenase
  • Quinone oxidoreductase
  • 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase
  • D-glycerate dehydrogenase
  • Formate dehydrogenase

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Pyruvate Dehydrogenase. It is a multi-enzyme complex with 5 coenzymes and 3 apo-enzymes, which favours oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl CoA.

 

Option B) Glutamate Dehydrogenase. Glutamate Dehydrogenase is involved in the reversible conversion of glutamate to α-ketoglutarate. While it involves NADH/NAD+ cofactors, it does not typically contain a Rossmann fold associated NADH domain.

 

Option C) ALA dehydratase. Involved in heme synthesis.

 

Ref: Harper, 30th edition, page no. 40

questions.text: A pediatric patient is brought to the emergency department with signs of ocular hypotension and apnea. The parents are concerned about the child's condition and have provided a history of recent medication use. It is crucial to determine which drug may have caused these symptoms in the infant. Drug capable of causing ocular hypotension with apnea in infants is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brimonidine

 

  • Brimonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to lower intraocular pressure in conditions such as glaucoma.
  • It acts by decreasing the production of aqueous humor and increasing its outflow, thereby reducing intraocular pressure.
  • While brimonidine is generally well-tolerated, it can have systemic side effects, particularly in infants.
  • The most concerning systemic side effect in this context is central nervous system depression, which can manifest as symptoms like apnea (temporary cessation of breathing).
  • Infants, especially premature ones, are more susceptible to such side effects.
  • Therefore, brimonidine is the drug most likely responsible for causing ocular hypotension with apnea in this case.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Timolol. Timolol is a beta-blocker commonly used to lower intraocular pressure. While it can have systemic side effects, including bradycardia and bronchospasm, it is not typically associated with apnea in infants.

 

Option C) Latanoprost. Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analog that lowers intraocular pressure by increasing the outflow of aqueous humor. It can cause side effects such as changes in iris color and eyelash growth. However, it is not known to cause apnea in infants.

 

Option D) Dorzolamide. Dorzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used in ophthalmology to reduce intraocular pressure. While it can cause ocular hypotension, it is not a common cause of apnea, especially in infants.

choices.text: The malignancy arises from naïve B cell
Increased risk of infections is present
Flow cytometry is required for confirmation of diagnosis
Cell have no expression of CD5+ but have high expression of CD23

questions.text: A 62-year-old elderly male presented with persistent fatigue and total leucocyte count of 50,000/μl. His peripheral smear was done and had the findings as shown. Which of the following is not correct about the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cell have no expression of CD5+ but have high expression of CD23

 

  • The given history of elderly male with leucocytosis and the peripheral smear showing “smudge cells” is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.
  • The diagnosis of CLL can be confirmed using flow cytometry demonstrating cells with CD5/CD23 expression.

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ig A

 

  • The above image shows a dimeric structure, characteristic of secretory IgA.
  • IgA immunoglobulin is the major antibody responsible for mucosal immunity.
  • Its serum levels are usually low. It is predominantly present in the extravascular secretions.
  • It is present in secretions such as milk, saliva, and tears, and in secretions of the respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts.
  • When present in the serum, it exists as a monomer similar to IgG.
  • However, when it is secreted, it exists as a dimer.
  • The dimeric structure consists of two monomers, which are stabilized by two additional polypeptides:
    • J chain, which stabilizes the molecule.
    • Secretory component, which is incorporated into the IgA when transported through the epithelial cell.

questions.text: In autopsy, the gastric mucosa shows the findings depicted in the picture below. What is the probable cause of death?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypothermia

 

  • The image illustrates a common feature in hypothermic deaths, characterized by numerous brown-black acute erosions found in the gastric mucosa. These are known as Wischnewski spots, erosions, or ulcers.
  • The mechanism underlying this phenomenon relates to hypothermia, causing increased histamine and serotonin levels, which in turn increases capillary permeability. This elevated capillary permeability disrupts the normal blood flow to the gastric mucosa, leading to the formation of these erosions.
  • Another key autopsy finding in hypothermic deaths is the presence of fat necrosis in the pancreas. This is considered to be a constant and pathognomonic (disease-specific) feature of such fatalities.
  • Additionally, in cases of hypothermic death, the post-mortem lividity (PML) often appears bright-pink in color due to the presence of oxy-haemoglobin, a form of hemoglobin that is saturated with oxygen.

choices.text: Provoked lower esophageal contractility

questions.text: Which among the following monitors is most commonly used to monitor the depth of anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bispectral index

 

  • The bispectral index is the most commonly used method to monitor the depth & determine the level of consciousness under anesthesia.
  • It is EEG-derived which shows the cerebral drug effect of an anesthetic drug. BIS ranges from 0-100.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents to the orthopedic clinic with a complaint of severe, localized pain in his right leg that has been bothering him for several months. He describes the pain as intense and deep, often occurring at night and disturbing his sleep. The pain is exacerbated by activity and relieved by taking over-the-counter nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). On physical examination, there is localized tenderness and a noticeable increase in warmth over a specific area in his right tibia. The patient has no history of trauma or recent injuries. Which of the following best describes the likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteoid osteoma

 

  • Osteoid osteoma is a benign bone tumor that commonly occurs in young adults.
  • It is characterized by intense, localized pain, especially at night, which is often relieved by NSAIDs.
  • The warmth and tenderness over a specific area are also typical findings.
  • These tumors are usually small and can be found in various bones, including the long bones like the tibia.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Stress fracture. Stress fractures are typically caused by repetitive mechanical stress on a bone, often due to overuse or increased physical activity. While they can cause localized pain, they do not usually result in severe, nocturnal pain relieved by NSAIDs. Stress fractures can be considered as a differential diagnosis, but they are less likely in this case.

 

Option B) Osteomyelitis. Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone that can cause localized pain, warmth, and tenderness, but it is usually associated with systemic symptoms such as fever and malaise. The chronicity and nocturnal pain pattern described in this case are not typical of osteomyelitis.

 

Option C) Ewing's sarcoma. Ewing's sarcoma is a rare type of bone cancer that primarily affects children and young adults. It can cause localized bone pain and swelling but typically presents with other symptoms such as fever, weight loss, and fatigue. The pain in Ewing's sarcoma is often constant and not typically relieved by NSAIDs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective for this case is to recognize the clinical features and presentation of osteoid osteoma, a benign bone tumor.
  • Osteoid osteoma typically presents with severe, nocturnal pain that responds to NSAIDs, localized tenderness, and sometimes warmth over a specific bone area. Radiological imaging, such as a CT scan or MRI, is often used to confirm the diagnosis.
  • Surgical or minimally invasive procedures can be performed to remove the tumor and alleviate the patient's symptoms.
  • Differential diagnosis is important to rule out other conditions that may present with similar symptoms.

choices.text: Cavernous sinus thrombosis
Lateral sinus thrombosis
Frontal lobe abscess

questions.text: A patient with ethmoid sinusitis develops fever with chills and rigors associated with chemosis, B/L proptosis and fever. The diagnosis goes in favor of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cavernous sinus thrombosis

 

  • Diagnosis mostly goes in favor of cavernous sinus thrombosis.
  • Ethmoid sinusitis can spread to the cavernous sinus through ophthalmic veins.
  • Onset of cavernous sinus thrombophlebitis is abrupt with chills and rigors. Patient is acutely ill.
  • Eyelids get swollen with chemosis and proptosis of eyeball.
  • Cranial nerves III, IV and VI which are related to the movements of eyeball get involved individually and sequentially causing total ophthalmoplegia.
  • Pupil becomes dilated and fixed, optic disc shows congestion and edema with diminution of vision.
  • Sensation in the distribution of V1 (ophthalmic division of CN V) is diminished.
  • CSF is usually normal.
  • Meningitis presents with fever, chills, and neck stiffness. Kernig's and Brudzinski’s sign is positive

choices.text: Secondary attack rate
Case fatality rate
Primary attack rate
Tertiary attack rate

questions.text: What is the term for the probability of infection occurring in susceptible individuals after they come into contact with an infectious person during the incubation period?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Secondary attack rate

 

  • The probability that infection will occur among susceptible persons following contact with an infectious person within the incubation period is called secondary attack rate (SAR).
  • SAR is a measure of Communicability of a disease.
  • It is calculated by the following formula:

 

Secondary attack rate (SAR) = (Number of exposed or susceptible persons developing the disease within the incubation period × 100) / (Total number of close or exposed contacts that are Susceptible).

 

  • Primary case is excluded from both numerator & denominator secondary attack rate measures the communicability of the disease/Infectivity.

choices.text: Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery
Free TRAM based on inferior epigastric artery
DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery
DIEP is a myocutaneous flap

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the flaps used in breast reconstruction.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DIEP is a myocutaneous flap

 

  • The DIEP flap is derived from the deep inferior epigastric artery and is a muscle sparing flap.
  • This statement given in the question is not accurate.
  • A myocutaneous flap, by definition, includes muscle.
  • The DIEP flap is differentiated from the TRAM flap by the fact that it spares the rectus abdominis muscle and uses only the skin, fat, and blood vessels for breast reconstruction.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery. TRAM stands for Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous. The pedicled TRAM flap relies primarily on the superior epigastric artery, which remains attached (or "pedicled") to its original blood supply. The flap is tunneled under the skin to the chest and used to reconstruct the breast.

 

Option B) Free TRAM based on inferior epigastric artery. The free TRAM flap involves removing a section of the abdominal tissue (including the rectus muscle) and its associated blood vessels (inferior epigastric arteries). This flap is then transplanted to the chest and connected to the chest's blood vessels using microsurgical techniques. It utilizes both the superior and inferior epigastric arteries.

 

Option C) DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery. The DIEP (Deep Inferior Epigastric Perforator) flap is similar to the free TRAM flap but does not involve the removal of the rectus muscle. Instead, only the blood vessels (or "perforators") and the skin and fat are removed. It is based solely on the deep inferior epigastric artery. The DIEP flap reduces post-operative abdominal weakness and complications because it spares the abdominal muscles.

choices.text: Chronic renal disease
History of amenorrhea

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to OCP use?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thromboembolism

 

  • Thromboembolism is an absolute contraindication to OCP use.
  • The WHO has defined Medical Eligibility Criteria (MEC) for using contraceptives. These are:
    • 1: No restriction of use
    • 2: A condition where the advantages of the method generally outweigh the risks
    • 3: A condition where the risks of using the method outweigh the benefits (Relative Contraindication)
    • 4: Unacceptable health risk if the method is used (Absolute Contraindication)
  • Absolute Contraindications (MEC 4) of Combined OCPs are:
    • Breastfeeding and < 6 weeks postpartum
    • Not breastfeeding; < 21 days postpartum with risk factors for Venous Thromboembolism
    • Age ≥ 35 years with smoking ≥ 15 cigarettes/day
    • Hypertension with systolic BP ≥ 160 OR Diastolic BP ≥ 100 mmHg
    • Hypertension with vascular disease
    • History of DVT/Pulmonary embolism
    • Acute DVT/Pulmonary embolism
    • Major surgery with prolonged immobilization
    • Known thrombogenic mutations (e.g. Factor V Leiden, prothrombin mutation, protein S, C, antithrombin deficiency)
    • Current and history of ischaemic heart disease
    • Stroke (history of Cerebrovascular disease)
    • Complicated valvular heart disease
    • Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome
    • Migraine with aura (any age)
    • Current breast cancer
    • Severe cirrhosis
    • Hepatocellular adenoma/carcinoma

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Absolute Contraindications (MEC 4) of Combined OCPs are:
    • Breastfeeding and < 6 weeks postpartum
    • Not breastfeeding; < 21 days postpartum with risk factors for Venous Thromboembolism
    • Age ≥ 35 years with smoking ≥ 15 cigarettes/day
    • Hypertension with systolic BP ≥ 160 OR Diastolic BP ≥ 100 mmHg
    • Hypertension with vascular disease
    • History of DVT/Pulmonary embolism
    • Acute DVT/ Pulmonary embolism
    • Major surgery with prolonged immobilization
    • Known thrombogenic mutations (e.g. Factor V Leiden, prothrombin mutation, protein S, C, antithrombin deficiency)
    • Current and history of ischaemic heart disease
    • Stroke (history of Cerebrovascular disease)
    • Complicated valvular heart disease
    • Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome
    • Migraine with aura (any age)
    • Current breast cancer
    • Severe cirrhosis
    • Hepatocellular adenoma/carcinoma

 

Ref: https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789241549158

choices.text: Congenital rubella syndrome
Congenital herpes simplex virus infection
Congenital cytomegalovirus infection

questions.text: An infant is brought to OPD with hepatosplenomegaly and thrombocytopenia. Neuroimaging with CT reveals periventricular calcifications. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Congenital cytomegalovirus infection

 

  • Congenital CMV is reported to be the commonest congenital infection.
  • The overall transmission rate with primary infection is 30% and 10% of all babies infected are symptomatic.
  • Congenital infection can affect all organ systems.
  • Periventricular calcification is characteristic.
  • The diagnosis of congenital CMV is confirmed by a positive IgM in the first two weeks of life.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Congenital Rubella Syndrome. Rubella causes most severe form of intra uterine infection. If infection sets within 11 weeks POG – 90% defects, if 11-12 weeks – 33% defects chances. More the weeks pass, less is the frequency of having CRS infections. Presentation is similar like measles rash but rash appears on day 1 & lasts for 3 days (3 days measles). Triad – congenital heart disease (MC – PDA; Least Common – ASD), Cataract and Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL).

 

Option B) Congenital herpes simplex virus infection. The transmission of HSV to babies usually occurs during delivery in mothers who develop primary genital herpes at that time. Infected babies may be asymptomatic or have fulminant disease. Presents with vesicular eruption on to skin, eyes and mouth. CNS disease that presents as meningitis with seizures and altered sensorium. Diagnosis is by Tzanck smear of the skin lesions, culture or PCR of lesions or cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Option C) Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs due to maternal primary infection, which is generally subclinical may lead to fetal infection and disease. The transmissibility increases but the risk of fetal disease decreases with advancing pregnancy. It presents with a triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracerebral calcifications.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male has the following buccal mucosa finding. After three days, he presents to your OPD with a rash. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Measles

 

  • Based on the given information, the most likely diagnosis for the 3-year-old male with buccal mucosa findings followed by a rash after three days is Measles.
  • Measles is a viral illness that commonly affects children, and it typically starts with flu-like symptoms such as fever, cough, runny nose, and red, watery eyes.
  • One of the hallmark signs of measles is the presence of Koplik spots, which are small, white, grain-like lesions that appear on the buccal mucosa.
  • A rash usually follows the appearance of Koplik spots, which typically starts on the face and neck and then spreads to the rest of the body.
  • If you suspect that a child has measles, it is essential to isolate them and refer them to a healthcare facility for further evaluation and treatment.
  • Lymphadenopathy may be present.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Leukoplakia is a benign condition that is not associated with fever and rash.

 

Option C) Scarlet fever is caused by beta-hemolytic streptococci and presents with a URI and a sandpaper-like rash.

 

Option D) Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness that is associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It presents with fever, rash, and conjunctivitis but lacks Koplik spots.

questions.text: Which type of aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fluent aphasia

 

  • Regions anterior to the central sulcus are motor areas and posterior are sensory areas. Hence, temporal gyrus involvement causes a fluent aphasia.

 

 

Ref: KV Krishna Das, textbook of Medicine, 5th edition

choices.text: His identical twin brothers
Umbilical cord transplant
An HLA identical matched unrelated donor who is blood type O-
His HLA identical 50-year-old brother who is otherwise healthy and is blood type O+

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia, with a blood type of O negative blood group, presents to the transplant clinic to discuss proceeding with an allogeneic stem cell transplant. Which of the following would be an optimal donor?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) His HLA identical 50-year-old brother who is otherwise healthy and is blood type O+

 

  • Due to the decreased risk of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) with related transplants, related donor transplants are still favored over unrelated donor transplants.
  • Rh incompatibility has no impact on the success of transplants (Rh antigen is only found on the surface of RBCs, not on the parenchymal cells of the graft).

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Syngeneic transplantation (donation from identical twins) has been shown to increase the risk of relapse in cases of hematologic malignancies and is therefore not a source of donor that is advised.

 

Option B) Umbilical cord transplant is not usually recommended.

 

Option C) While ABO compatibility is vital when selecting a donor, this is merely a slight ABO discrepancy.

 

Ref: Harrison, Transplant, Chapter 104

choices.text: Superficial peroneal nerve

questions.text: A patient underwent a coronary bypass graft with the great saphenous vein. The patient now complains of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Saphenous nerve

 

  • The patient's symptoms of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot indicate possible damage to the saphenous nerve, which can occur during a venous cut down procedure to access the great saphenous vein for coronary bypass graft.
  • The saphenous nerve is a major cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve and is the longest nerve in the body.
  • After arising from the posterior division of the femoral nerve, it enters and exits the adductor canal before piercing the fascia lata between the gracilis and sartorius muscles.
  • From there, it runs along the medial border of the tibia alongside the great saphenous vein and supplies sensation to the skin over the patella, knee, leg, and foot, up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint.
  • During a venous cut down procedure, injury to the saphenous nerve is common due to its proximity to the great saphenous vein.
  • The resulting sensory loss typically affects the medial aspect of the knee, leg, and foot.

 

 

 

 

  • The saphenous nerve is the longest and terminal cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve.
  • It travels alongside the great saphenous vein in the leg.
  • Sensory Distribution: Provides sensation to the medial aspect of the leg and the foot.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation over the medial side of the leg and foot.

 

Other options:
