Option A) Superficial Peroneal Nerve.

 

  • This nerve originates from the common peroneal nerve (a branch of the sciatic nerve).
  • It runs in the lateral compartment of the leg.
  • Sensory Distribution: Supplies sensation to the dorsum (top) of the foot and a small area over the lateral aspect of the lower leg.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution and potential weakness in eversion of the foot.

 

Option C) Femoral Nerve.

 

  • Arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L4).
  • Motor Functions: It supplies the anterior compartment muscles of the thigh which are primarily responsible for hip flexion and knee extension.
  • Sensory Distribution: Over the anterior thigh and medial aspect of the leg (via the saphenous nerve, its branch).
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Weakness in hip flexion and knee extension along with sensory loss over its distribution.

 

Option D) Sural Nerve.

 

  • This nerve is formed by branches from both the tibial and common peroneal nerves.
  • It runs along the posterior and then lateral side of the calf.
  • Sensory Distribution: Supplies the posterolateral aspect of the leg and the lateral side of the foot.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

choices.text: Vein of Galen malformation
Dandy Walker syndrome
Venous sinus thrombosis

questions.text: A child presents with left to right shunt and high output cardiac failure. The following is his MRI. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vein of Galen malformation

 

  • The MRI shown is suggestive of Vein of Galen Malformation (VOGM).

 

VOGM

 

 

  • C/F: Newborn with high output cardiac failure with intracranial bruit
  • Type of A-V fistula
  • Doppler: Large midline vessel seen
  • MRI: Large flow void.
  • CT angiography: Giant vein of galen draining into straight sinus.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Dandy-walker malformation. Posterior cranial fossa malformation.

choices.text: Least affected by hypoxia
Smallest nerve fibers

questions.text: All the following statements are true regarding the C type nerve fibers except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Preganglionic autonomic

 

  • The C type fibers are unmyelinated nerve fibers.
  • They are the smallest nerve fibers (0.3-1.3 μm in diameter) and have the lowest nerve conduction velocity.
  • The dorsal root C fibers are involved in the perception of pain and temperature.
  • The sympathetic (autonomic) C fibers are postganglionic (not preganglionic).
  • The C fibers are least susceptible to hypoxia (least affected).

 

Ref: Ganong's Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, page no. 95

questions.text: Which of the following phospholipid possess antigen property?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cardiolipin

 

  • It is the major lipid of Inner Mitochondrial Membranes and maintains the structure and function of ETC complexes.
  • The structure contains one glycerol attached to two phosphatidic acids. So also known as diphosphatidyl glycerol.
  • It is the only Phospholipid which possesses antigenicity, usually phospholipids are not antigenic.
  • Decreased levels of cardiolipin or alteration in its structure or metabolism cause diseases:
    • Barth Syndrome: a rare X-linked disorder, occurs due to defect in cardiolipin remodeling. Patients have muscle weakness, neutropenia and cardiomyopathy.
    • Antiphospholipid Syndrome: a thrombotic condition which leads to abortion. Anticardiolipin antibodies are found.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Plasmalogens are found in bio membranes in brain and muscle.

 

Option C) Phosphatidylinositol acts as a second messenger and plays a vital role in the mediation of hormone action on bio membranes.

 

Option D) Dipalmitoyl Lecithin/Di Palmitoyl Phosphatidyl Choline is the most abundant phospholipid of cell membrane, largest body store of choline and a major constituent of lung surfactant.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan, 9th edition, page no. 108

questions.text: A patient was started on antihypertensive drugs. Few days later, the patient presented with the following picture. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lisinopril

 

  • The given picture is suggestive of angioedema.
  • The antihypertensive drug that can lead to the development of angioedema is ACE-Inhibitors – Lisinopril in the given option.
  • Angioedema caused by ACE inhibitors is a class effect, and patients who experience this side effect should not be given any other ACE inhibitors.
  • The other side effects of ACE-Inhibitors are:
    • Cough
    • Taste disturbances (Dysguesia)
    • Orthostatic hypotension
    • Hyperkalemia
  • They are contraindicated in Pregnancy and in patients with B/L Renal artery stenosis.

questions.text: What is defined as the emotional release and discharge after consciously reliving a painful experience that has been repressed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abreaction

 

Abreaction: This term specifically refers to the process of bringing repressed traumatic experiences to consciousness, accompanied by the appropriate emotional response, often leading to relief.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Catharsis: This is a broader term for the release of emotional tension and can occur without specifically reliving a traumatic event.

 

Option C) Venting out: This generally means expressing feelings, especially of anger or frustration, but doesn't necessarily imply working through repressed trauma.

 

Option D) Guided relaxation: This involves being led (usually verbally) to a state of relaxation, and is not directly related to processing repressed emotions.

 

  • Therefore, "abreaction" best describes the conscious reliving of a painful, repressed experience and the subsequent emotional discharge.

 

Educational Objective: In abreaction, an attempt is made to bring the unconscious memories and emotions into conscious awareness using hypnosis, medications and other techniques.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No. 860

choices.text: Rupture of valve
Calcification and fibrosis
Hypertrophy of ventricular wall
Hypertrophy of the atrial wall

questions.text: A 47-year-old female patient with a long-standing history of rheumatic heart disease was admitted to hospital due to severe breathlessness. She died on the 3rd day following admission. The mitral valve shows the following findings on autopsy. What is the cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcification and Fibrosis

 

  • The illustration depicts rheumatic heart disease and mitral stenosis with a fish mouth or buttonhole appearance.
  • Calcification and fibrosis are the causes.
  • RHD is primarily identified by mitral stenosis, for which it is essentially the primary cause, and deforming fibrotic valvular disease.
  • The leaflet thickening, commissural fusion and shortening, and thickening and fusing of the tendinous cords are the three primary anatomic alterations of the mitral valve in chronic RHD.
  • "Fish mouth" or "buttonhole" stenosis are caused by calcification and fibrous bridging over the valvular commissures.

choices.text: Basal cell carcinoma
Squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: An HIV patient with following mucosal lesion came for consultation to a dermatology OPD. What can be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kaposi sarcoma

 

  • This is based on the clinical presentation and histopathological findings provided.
  • Kaposi's sarcoma is characterized by multiple, firm, non-tender, violaceous plaques and is associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8).
  • The presence of leukopenia and a low CD4 count further supports the diagnosis of an HIV-infected individual.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Basal cell carcinoma. It usually presents as a pearly nodular lesion with telangiectasia and rarely occurs in the oral cavity.

 

Option C) Melanoma in the oral cavity is rare and typically presents as a rapidly enlarging dark lesion.

 

Option D) Squamous cell carcinoma. It tends to present as an ulcerative lesion with indurated margins and can be more common in the oral cavity but does not match the description of firm, violaceous plaques.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When an HIV patient presents with firm, violaceous plaques in the oral cavity and skin, Kaposi's sarcoma should be suspected.
  • Diagnosis can be confirmed with a biopsy showing spindle-cell neoplasm positive for CD34 and HHV-8.
  • Treatment includes antiretroviral therapy and, if necessary, chemotherapy.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th Edition, page no. 25.37; Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology, 4th edition, Page no. 32, 2022

questions.text: A 55-year-old multigravida with history of frequently micturation due to coughing, laughing & sneezing. The diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stress incontinence

 

  • This is stress incontinence i.e., leakage of urine on stress (increased abdominal pressure) like coughing or laughing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Urge incontinence. This is when there is urinary incontinence immediately preceded by a sense of urgency. It is due to an overactive bladder.

 

Option C) Neurogenic bladder. This can lead to overflow incontinence due to loss of bladder control.

 

Option D) UTI. This presents as burning micturition, frequency and hesitancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Ref: Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition, Page no. 607

choices.text: Whole Bowel Irrigation

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 10-20 ferrous sulfate tablets. Arterial blood gas revealed acidosis. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Whole Bowel Irrigation

 

  • Whole bowel Irrigations with PEG (polyethylene glycol) @ 500-1500 mL/hour administered orally/via Ryles tube until rectal contents are clear can be used in following poisoning (LIMPS): Lithium, Iron, Other Metals, Body Packers, SR preparation (sustained release preparations)
  • Iron poisoning:
    • Iron pills are radio-opaque and can be detected on x-ray.
    • Gastric lavage is no longer practiced and not effective evidence-based practices.
    • Dose of >65mg/kg of elemental iron causes death due to cardiopulmonary failure (MCC).
    • Gastric outlet obstruction develops as late complication.
    • I.V deferoxamine is the antidote of choice in acute iron poisoning.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Activated charcoal is to be administered within 1-2 hours of ingestion. It is contraindicated in patients with low GCS, heavy metals, alcohols, corrosives, petroleum poisoning as they are not effective and may increase risk of aspiration.

 

Option C) Dimercaprol is used in the treatment of Arsenic and mercury poisoning.

 

Option D) D-penicillamine is used in treatment of Wilson’s disease.

 

Ref: Harrison, 21st Edition, page no. 2343, 2588

choices.text: Restriction of water intake and wait and watch
Trans urethral resection of prostate

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the initial management of the irritative urethral symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha blocker

 

  • Alpha blocker will be used for the initial management of the irritative urethral symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia.

 

ALPHA BLOCKERS

 

  • Most commonly preferred ones are α1A blockers like Tamsulosin and Silodosin.
  • They do not lead to postural hypotension, which can be seen with selective α1 blockers like Prazosin, Doxazosin etc.
  • Later block α1 receptors in the blood vessels as well, leading to vasodilation.
  • However, these drugs have no effect on the size of the prostate gland.

choices.text: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor

questions.text: Which of the following is an epithelial tumor of the stomach?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gastric adenocarcinoma

 

  • Gastric adenocarcinoma is an epithelial tumor of the stomach.
  • Adenocarcinoma is the most common malignancy (90% cases) of the stomach.

questions.text: A 52-year-old diabetic man presented with the following skin lesions. What could be the probable fungal pathogen for this hypopigmented skin lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malassezia furfur

 

  • The hypopigmented lesions in the image is Pityriasis versicolor (Tinea versicolor).
  • It is caused by Malassezia furfur.
  • Malassezia furfur causes Tinea versicolor, Folliculitis and seborrheic dermatitis.
  • Seborrheic dermatitis manifests as erythematous pruritic scaly lesions seen in the eyebrows, moustache, nasolabial folds and scalp; scalp lesions seen in babies is called cradle cap.
  • Diagnosis: Specimen – Skin scrapings – shows yeast like cells with short, branched filaments
  • Culture: SDA with olive oil layer (lipophilic fungi)
  • Treatment: Topical creams and lotions like selenium sulfide shampoo, ketoconazole shampoo, terbinafine cream and ciclopirox cream.

 

Ref: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th edition, Page No. 599

choices.text: Cary Blair medium

questions.text: Which of the following transport mediums is helpful in transporting stool samples in case of diarrhoea?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cary Blair medium

 

  • Transport media are helpful for fastidious organisms.

 

 

Ref: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th edition, Chapter 2, Page No. 29

questions.text: A 20-year-old female of thin stature, presented to the OPD with redness, irritation and watering in both eyes for the past 1 month. She had a history of loss of appetite & weight. Examination showed a pinkish white nodule with ulcerated apex at the limbus. What would be the investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mantoux test

 

  • Image shows pinkish, white nodule at the limbus – PHLYCTEN
  • Thin stature, loss of appetite & weight – suggestive of TB
  • Nodular – allergic response to endogenous allergens – especially against tubercular protein.
  • Mnemonic: phlycTEN: Tubercular antigen, Endogenous antigens, Nodule at limbus
  • Investigations:
  1. For TB – TC (Total count), DC (Differential count), ESR
  2. X-ray chest, Mantoux test

 

Ref: Comprehensive ophthalmology, AK Khurana, Conjunctiva, 6th edition, page no. 84

choices.text: Chi Square test
Paired T test
Standard error of the mean

questions.text: An investigation was conducted to evaluate the nutritional status of young children residing in both rural and urban regions. Among the participants, 30 children from rural areas and 20 children from urban areas were found to be malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chi Square test

 

  • The Chi Square test can be used to determine whether there is a significant association or relationship between two categorical variables.
  • In this case, the two variables are the nutritional status (malnourished or not malnourished) and the location (rural or urban), both of which are Qualitative characters.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Paired T test is used when comparing the means of two related samples, such as before and after measurements for the same group.

 

Option C) Standard error of the mean is a measure of the variability of sample means.

 

Option D) ANOVA is used to compare the means of three or more groups.

 

  • These tests are not appropriate for analyzing the relationship between two categorical variables as in this case.

questions.text: What is the function of the muscle marked in the image below, at the metacarpophalangeal joint?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flexion

 

 

 

  • Lumbricals are the muscles that cause flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joints.
  • The tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus in the palm give rise to the 4 lumbrical (worm-like) muscles.
  • Medial two lumbricals are bipennate and originate from the flexor digitorum profundus tendons associated with the middle and ring fingers and the ring and little fingers, respectively; Supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve
  • Lateral two lumbricals are unipennate muscles, originating from the flexor digitorum profundus tendons associated with index and middle fingers, respectively; Supplied by digital branches of the median nerve
  • The lumbrical muscles have tendons that pass over the outer side of each finger and attach to the extensor hood. They are located in front of the deep transverse metacarpal ligaments.
  •  The muscle marked in the image above in the question, at the metacarpophalangeal joint, is likely involved in finger movement.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Flexion:

 

  • The primary function of the muscle marked is to facilitate flexion of the finger at the metacarpophalangeal joint.
  • Flexion involves bending the finger, reducing the angle between the metacarpal bone (in the palm) and the proximal phalanx (the first bone of the finger).
  • This muscle contributes to the closing of the fingers into a grip.
  • Muscles involved are Flexor Digitorum Profundus, Flexor Digitorum Superficialis, Flexor Pollicis Longus, Flexor Carpi Ulnaris and Flexor Carpi Radialis. These muscles flex the wrist.

 

Option B. Extension:

 

  • Extension of the finger is the opposite movement of flexion.
  • It involves straightening the finger, increasing the angle between the metacarpal bone and the proximal phalanx.
  • The muscle in question is not primarily responsible for extension.
  • Muscles involved are Extensor Digitorum, Extensor Pollicis Longus, Extensor Carpi Ulnaris and Extensor Carpi Radialis.

 

Option C. Adduction:

 

  • Adduction of the finger would involve moving the finger toward the midline or toward adjacent fingers.
  • The muscle in the image is not oriented to perform adduction.
  • Adduction of the fingers typically involves the intrinsic muscles of the hand, which are located within the hand itself.

 

Option D. Abduction:

 

  • Abduction of the finger would involve moving the finger away from the midline or away from adjacent fingers.
  • The muscle in the image is not positioned to perform abduction.
  • The specific muscles responsible for abduction are part of the dorsal interossei and palmar interossei muscle group.

questions.text: Which of the following ions is involved in peripheral oxygen sensing chemoreceptors?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Potassium

 

  • Potassium is involved in peripheral oxygen sensing chemoreceptors.
  • Chemoreceptors are made up of two types of cells, type I or glomus cells and type II or sustentacular cells.
  • Glomus cells have afferent nerve endings, which are stimulated by hypoxia.
  • Type II cells are glial cells and provide support for type I cells.
  • Type I glomus cells (carotid and aortic body) have O2-sensitive K+ channels.
  • Conductance of these channels is reduced proportionally to the degree of hypoxia resulting in K+ efflux → depolarization of cell and causes Ca+ influx → Excitation of afferent nerve ending.

choices.text: Coenzyme + prosthetic group

questions.text: Alcohol dehydrogenase requires oxidized NAD+ for catalytic activity. In the reaction catalyzed by ADH, an alcohol is oxidized to an aldehyde as NAD+ is reduced to NADH and dissociates from the enzyme. The NAD+ is functioning as a:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coenzyme + co-substrates

 

  • Coenzymes + co-substrates are small organic molecules that associate transiently with an enzyme and leave the enzyme in a changed form.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Heterotropic effectors are not substrates.

 

Option C) Coenzyme + prosthetic groups are small organic molecules which associate permanently with an enzyme and are returned to their original form on the enzyme.

 

Option D) Cofactors are metal ions.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan, 9th edition, page no. 50

choices.text: Lateral internal sphincterotomy

questions.text: What is the procedure done shown in the image below, for a patient with chronic perianal discharge despite treatment with multiple courses of antibiotics?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Seton insertion

 

  • The postoperative image suggests the use of seton for fistula in ano.

 

Other options: 

 

Option A) Stapled hemorrhoidopexy. A minimally invasive surgical technique used to treat internal hemorrhoids by repositioning prolapsed tissue back to its normal anatomical position with a circular stapling device.

 

Option C) Thiersch stitch. Thiersch's wiring involves placing a steel wire or a silastic/nylon tape around the anal canal. It is now rarely done due to post-operative problems such as chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation.

 

Option D) Lateral internal sphincterotomy is done for fissure in ano, and is not related to the image shown.

questions.text: Which one of the following drugs inhibits neutrophil recruitment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Colchicine

 

  • Colchicine is primarily used to treat gout and familial Mediterranean fever.
  • One of its mechanisms of action is the inhibition of neutrophil migration into inflamed tissues, thereby reducing inflammation.
  • It disrupts the microtubules inside cells, including neutrophils, affecting their mobility and reducing their recruitment to sites of inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Montelukast. Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist used mainly for asthma and allergic rhinitis. While it can reduce inflammation, its primary action is not on neutrophil recruitment.

 

Option B) Sodium Cromolyn. Sodium cromolyn is a mast cell stabilizer used to treat conditions like asthma and allergic rhinitis. It prevents the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators from mast cells but doesn't directly inhibit neutrophil recruitment.

 

Option D) Febuxostat. Febuxostat is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor used for the treatment of chronic gout. It reduces uric acid production but doesn't specifically inhibit neutrophil recruitment.

 

  • Therefore, Colchicine is the drug that inhibits neutrophil recruitment, making option C the correct answer.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in the vertex presentation with complete flexion attitude of head?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Suboccipito-bregmatic diameter

 

  • Suboccipito-bregmatic diameter (9.5 cm) is seen in vertex presentation with a complete flexion attitude of the head.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A mother brings her male child with clinical features of recurrent Urinary tract infection. On examination, the child was febrile. An Ultrasound examination reveals the presence of bilateral hydroureteronephrosis. A diagnosis of posterior urethral valve is suspected. What is the investigation of choice for posterior urethral valve?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Voiding Cystourethroscopy

 

POSTERIOR URETHRAL VALVE

 

  • PUV occurs in male child.
  • Diagnosis is most commonly made antenatally with ultrasound.
  • USG demonstrates bilateral hydronephrosis above a distended bladder giving a key hole appearance.
  • Investigation will involve a voiding cystourethrogram, with the dilatation of the urethra above the valves demonstrable on a voiding cystourethrogram/micturating cystourethrogram (MCU).
  • The bladder is hypertrophied and often shows diverticula.
  • Typically, there is vesicoureteric reflux into dilated upper tracts.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Anterograde urethroscopy is used for posterior urethral pathologies.

 

Option B) Cystourethroscopy has less or no significance in diagnosis of PUV.

 

Option D) Retrograde urethroscopy is used for anterior urethral pathologies

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 555, Page No. 10988

choices.text: Intravenous fluids with S.C. long-acting insulin
Intravenous fluids with I.V. regular insulin

questions.text: A patient with diabetes mellitus for the past 5 years presents with vomiting and abdominal pain. She is non-compliant with medication and appears dehydrated. Investigations revealed a blood sugar value of 500 mg/dL and the presence of ketone bodies. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intravenous fluids with I.V. regular insulin

 

  • History is suggestive of DKA occurring in the presence of absolute insulin deficiency producing glucotoxicity and ketoacidosis with significant dehydration. Hence, treatment initially aimed at correction of fluid deficit and bridging with insulin initiation.
  • Any form of insulin in IV form acts similarly. Only subcutaneously produces differences in half-life.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Intravenous fluids with S.C. long-acting insulin. IV insulin is required to correct glucotoxicity.

 

Option B) IV fluids alone reduce CBG by 150-200 mg/dL and reduce acidosis, however, insulin infusion is required for correction of ketoacidosis completely.

 

Option C) IV insulin alone will not correct fluid deficit in DKA.

 

Ref: Harrison, 21st edition, DKA, Chapter 405

questions.text: A female patient presented with fatigue. Routine complete blood count analysis showed hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, MCV of 60fL, and RBC count of 5 million. A peripheral smear showed microcytic hypochromic anemia. Which of the following is the next best investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HbA2 levels

 

  • A peripheral blood smear with microcytic hypochromic cells and a Mentzer index of less than 13 indicates thalassemia.
  • As a result, HbA2 levels (which are elevated in thalassemia) must be tested next.
  • The Mentzer index, also known as the MCV/RBC count, can be used to distinguish thalassemia from iron-deficiency anaemia (IDA).
  • In both IDA and thalassemia, MCV (mean corpuscular volume) and MCH (mean corpuscular haemoglobin) are low.
  • RBC count may be normal in thalassemia but decreased in IDA.
  • A lower RBC count in IDA indicates a smaller denominator, resulting in a higher MCV/RBC ratio.
  • Mentzer index is:
    • More than 13 in iron-deficiency anemia
    • Less than 13 in thalassemia
  • Alpha- and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively. This leads to precipitation of the excess (unpaired) chains, interfering with red blood cell (RBC) production and survival.
  • Clinical features in thalassemia include anemia, jaundice, skeletal deformities including facial deformities, changes in body habits, growth impairment, and hepatosplenomegaly. Due to frequent blood transfusions, iron overload is also seen.
  • Peripheral smear is likely to show microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells, teardrop cells, and some coarse basophilic stippling in certain cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Hypochromic Anemia:

questions.text: A patient presents with a unilateral throbbing headache, photophobia, and excessive lacrimation. He also complains of hemifacial pain on clenching of teeth. On examination, pupillary reflex, light reflex, and accommodation reflex are normal. Which of the following marked nerves is involved in the above scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3

 

  • The above patient presents with features suggesting an involvement of the trigeminal nerve.
  • The structure marked 3 is the trigeminal nerve.
  • The various clinical features associated with trigeminal nerve injury are:
    1. Facial pain: Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition characterized by severe facial pain, often described as sharp, stabbing, or electric shock-like sensations. The pain is typically triggered by routine activities such as eating, talking, or touching specific areas of the face.
    2. Sensory abnormalities: The trigeminal nerve carries sensory information from the face, including touch, temperature, and pain. When affected, sensory abnormalities may manifest as numbness, tingling, or altered sensation in the face. The distribution of these sensory disturbances depends on which branches of the trigeminal nerve are involved.
    3. Facial muscle weakness: The trigeminal nerve also supplies motor fibres to the muscles involved in chewing, such as the muscles of mastication. In certain conditions, such as trigeminal neuropathy or facial nerve palsy involving the trigeminal nerve, weakness or paralysis of these muscles can occur, leading to difficulty in chewing and controlling facial expressions.
    4. Corneal reflex abnormalities: The ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve is responsible for the corneal reflex, which involves blinking in response to corneal stimulation. Disorders affecting the trigeminal nerve may result in a diminished or absent corneal reflex on the affected side.
    5. Headache: Some disorders involving the trigeminal nerve, such as trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (e.g., cluster headaches), can cause severe headaches on one side of the head. These headaches often occur in close proximity to the trigeminal nerve distribution.

 

 

 

Other marked structures:

 

  • 1: Optic nerve
  • 2: Abducent nerve
  • 4: Vestibulo cochlear nerve

 

Let’s discuss all the marked structures:

 

Option A) Optic Nerve (II). The optic nerve is responsible for transmitting visual information from the retina to the brain. It is purely sensory in function. It begins at the retina, passes through the optic canal of the sphenoid bone, and joins the optic nerve of the opposite side at the optic chiasm. At this junction, fibers from the nasal half of each retina cross over.  Damage to the optic nerve can result in vision loss. Glaucoma, a condition with increased intraocular pressure, can damage the optic nerve and lead to blindness.

 

Option B) Abducent Nerve (VI). This nerve is a motor nerve that innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye (moves it laterally). It originates in the pons of the brainstem and travels through the superior orbital fissure to reach the orbit. Damage to this nerve can result in an inability to abduct the affected eye, leading to a condition called lateral rectus palsy. This can manifest as double vision (diplopia) when looking to the side.

 

Option C) Trigeminal Nerve (V). It is the largest cranial nerve and has both sensory and motor functions. Sensory functions include facial sensation, and the motor function is mainly for muscles of mastication (chewing).  It has three main branches: ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3). The nerve originates in the pons and exits the brainstem to innervate its various targets.  Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition where there's intense, stabbing pain along the path of the nerve. It's considered one of the most painful conditions in medicine.

 

Option D) Vestibulocochlear Nerve (VIII). It has two parts: the cochlear nerve (for hearing) and the vestibular nerve (for balance). It originates in the inner ear and enters the brainstem at the cerebellopontine angle. Damage can lead to issues like sensorineural hearing loss or balance disorders like vertigo.

BLUE PUNCTURE PROOF CONTAINER

choices.text: Allows CO2 flow of 20L/min
Commonly placed at left subcostal area
Used in closed technique of pneumoperitoneum
Blunt advancing tip reduces trauma

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about the device in the image.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Allows CO2 flow of 20/L min

 

  • The device is Veress needle used in closed technique of pneumoperitoneum.
  • The Veress needle typically allows for a slower insufflation rate of CO2, usually around 2 to 3 L/min when initiating pneumoperitoneum, not as high as 20L/min.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Commonly placed at left subcostal area. This statement is true. The Veress needle can be inserted at Palmer’s point, which is 3 cm below the left costal margin in the mid-clavicular line.

 

Option C) Used in closed technique of pneumoperitoneum. This is correct. The Veress needle is indeed used in the closed technique for establishing pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries.

 

Option D) Blunt advancing tip reduces trauma. This statement is true. The Veress needle has a spring-loaded blunt inner stylet that advances once the needle enters the peritoneal cavity, reducing the risk of trauma to internal organs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Veress needle, used for establishing pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgery, has a slow CO2 insufflation rate, is commonly placed at the left subcostal area, and features a blunt advancing tip to reduce internal organ trauma.
  • It does not typically allow for CO2 flow of 20L/min.
