questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with breathlessness and chest pain. She is a known case of mitral stenosis. Her pulse is irregularly irregular. No thrombus is seen on echocardiography. What is the best agent to prevent future thrombotic events?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oral warfarin

 

  • Patient with mitral stenosis presenting with AF requires anticoagulants if CHA2DS2VASC score is >1 (male), >2 (female).
  • Oral warfarin is indicated to prevent risk of thromboembolism.
  • The previous recommendation of Aspirin for score of 1 is no longer applicable as per recent guidelines (AHA and ESC).

 

 

 

  • Interpretation: Truly Low Risk – 0 in Male, 1 in female.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Dabigatran is a NOAC which haven't been extensively studied in valvular AF, however recent trial evidences show safety of Rivaroxaban in mild-moderate MS.

 

Option A and D are antiplatelet which are not indicated in prevention of thromboembolic phenomenon.

 

Ref: ESC valvular heart disease guidelines 2021

choices.text: The free fraction of the drug is pharmacologically active.
Acidic drugs generally bind to plasma albumin.
There is no effect of nephrotic syndrome on plasma protein binding.
Lignocaine is bound to alpha 1 acid glycoprotein.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about plasma protein binding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) There is no effect of nephrotic syndrome on plasma protein binding. 

 

PLASMA PROTEIN BINDING

 

  • Many natural substances circulate around the body partly free in plasma water and partly bound to plasma proteins, e.g., cortisol, thyroxine.
  • Similarly, drugs circulate in protein bound and free states, and the significance is that the free fraction is pharmacologically active whereas the protein bound component is a reservoir of drug that is inactive because of this binding.
  • Acidic drugs like barbiturates generally bind to plasma albumin.
  • Basic drugs like lignocaine (drugs ending with ‘ine’ are basic) bind to alpha acid glycoprotein.
  • Binding to albumin is quantitatively more important. In nephrotic syndrome and other conditions causing hypoproteinemia, protein binding will be altered.

choices.text: It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder
There is loss of function type of mutation
There are abnormal repeats of CUG
Abnormality is seen due to mutation in chromosome 6

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement regarding Huntington's chorea?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder

 

  • Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide repeat disorder.
  • The autosomal dominant condition known as Huntington disease (HD) is characterized histologically by the destruction of striatal neurons and clinically by increasing mobility abnormalities and dementia.
  • All portions of the body move jerkily, hyperkinetically, and occasionally in a dystonic manner (chorea); affected people may eventually develop parkinsonism with bradykinesia and stiffness.
  • The average course of the illness is around 15 years before death because of its persistent progression.
  • The polyglutamine trinucleotide repeat expansion illnesses have their origins in Huntington disease.
  • The HD gene, which is found on chromosome 4p16.3, produces the 348-kD huntingtin protein.
  • A section of CAG repeats in the gene's first exon encodes a polyglutamine region near the protein's N terminus.
  • The repeat is present in 6 to 35 copies in normal HD genes; when the number of repeats is increased beyond this level it is associated with disease.
  • There is an inverse relationship between repeat number and age of onset, such that longer repeats are associated with earlier onset.
  • The disease shows genetic anticipation and has an early-onset (2-3 decades) if inherited from the father.

questions.text: Which among the following cells produces immunoglobulins?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) B cells

 

  • B cells originate and mature in the Bone marrow itself.
  • During the process of synthesis, B cells acquire IgM and IgD as surface markers in the cell.
  • When antigen stimulates the B cells, they get transformed into plasma cells – secrete immunoglobulins.
  • Note that simultaneous expression of IgM and IgD on B-cell surface is due to alternate RNA splicing or differential RNA processing.

 

Ref: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th edition, Page No. 183

questions.text: Research is being conducted to find the association between aniline dye exposure and bladder cancer in workers who have worked in the industry for >20 years. Two groups were formed: one directly involved with dye handling and the other group consisting of office clerks not directly exposed to the dye. Years of occupation were noted from records. Then Bladder cancer cases were identified from both the groups in the current time. What type of study is being performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retrospective cohort study

 

  • The study given here is a retrospective cohort study.
  • A retrospective cohort study is when both the exposure and outcome have occurred before commencing the investigations and study.
  • The given question tells that the workers in the industry were divided into two groups, first are those who are directly exposed and second are clerical staff who are not directly exposed to the suspected carcinogen.
  • The incidence of bladder cancer among these two groups is studied going backward tracking their records.
  • Therefore, it’s a retrospective cohort study.
  • A simple comparison between these studies and an example is shown below:

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Prospective cohort study involves following a group over a time span till the development of outcome.

 

Option C) Case-control study. A case-control study involves comparing groups with a specific outcome (cases) with a rather healthy group (controls) and assessing their exposure history. In this case, workers are divided into groups based on their exposure status and the development of bladder cancer.

 

Option D) Intervention and response is not a type of epidemiological study design.

questions.text: Which part of urethra would be injured in the pictures given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bulbar

 

  • Straddle injuries lead to rupture of bulbous urethra. This can occur with a sharp blow to the perineum.
  • Diagnosis is made by retrograde urethrography.
  • Suprapubic cystostomy is performed.
  • Delayed urethroplasty (2-3 months later) is the surgical treatment of choice.
  • Presentation:
    • Blood at urethral meatus
    • Not being able to pass urine
    • Urine building up in the bladder (distension)
    • Butterfly shaped perineal hematoma

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery, 28th edition, page no. 1540-1541

questions.text: Which of the following progesterone medications is commonly used in HRT in menopausal women to protect the uterus from the potential risks of estrogen therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medroxyprogesterone acetate

 

  • Medroxyprogesterone acetate is the most commonly used as HRT for menopausal women to protect the uterus from hyperplasia/malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Micronized progesterone is commonly used in pregnancy in women at risk of preterm labor.

 

Option C) Norethindrone and Option D) Levonorgestrel are usually part of combined contraceptive pills. LNG is also used as an intra uterine device (Mirena).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medroxyprogesterone acetate is the most commonly used as HRT for menopausal women to protect the uterus from hyperplasia/malignancy.

 

Ref:  Speroff’s Gynecology, 9th edition, Page no. 1420

choices.text: Posterior wall MI
Inferior wall MI
Anterior wall MI

questions.text: Patient with DM, HTN presented with abdominal pain and diaphoresis. Examination shows HR 44/min and BP 116/60mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inferior wall MI

 

  • Inferior wall MI is associated with bradycardia due to ischemia to AV node supplied by RCA.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Posterior wall MI. Isolated Posterior wall MI usually doesn’t present with bradycardia.

 

Option C) Anterior wall MI is associated with tachycardia representing heart failure.

 

Option D) RV MI presents with hypotension and requires IV fluids to maintain adequate preload.

 

Ref: Harrison, 21st Edition, ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction, Chapter 275

questions.text: A patient, who was on steroids for the treatment of chronic urticaria, presents to the emergency department with acute worsening of respiratory symptoms. He says that he has been having nocturnal cough for last several weeks. A hemogram revealed elevated eosinophils. Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL) specimen following bronchoscopy showed the presence of certain larvae as shown in the image below. Identify the causative organism.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

  • The presence of eosinophilia in an immunosuppressed patient with respiratory symptoms and BAL revealing rhabditiform larvae is suggestive of disseminated strongyloidiasis caused by Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

STRONGYLOIDIASIS

 

  • Strongyloides are ovoviviparous.
  • The transmission of infection occurs through penetration of the skin by filariform larvae in the soil.
  • Then, they migrate to the small intestine.
  • The larvae moult twice and become adult female worms in the small intestine.
  • The eggs laid in the mucosa of the intestine hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage).
  • These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.
  • The life cycle of strongyloides is shown below.

 

 

  • It is generally a benign and asymptomatic condition.
  • In some cases, there may be cutaneous, pulmonary, and intestinal manifestations.
  • Pulmonary manifestations occur when the larva escapes from the pulmonary capillaries into the alveoli leading to bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, and asthmatic symptoms.
  • The term larva currens (meaning 'racing larvae') has been applied to the rapidly progressing linear or serpiginous urticarial tracks caused by migrating filariform larvae of Strongyloides stercoralis.
  • These often follow autoinfection and start perianally.
  • Disseminated Strongyloidiasis is seen in immunodeficient individuals.
  • Larva currens is shown in the image below.
  • Visceral larva migrans is caused by the migration of larvae of nonhuman species of nematodes that infect via the oral route.

 

 

  • Etiological agents causing visceral larva migrans:
    1. Human nematode: Ascaris lumbricoides, Strongyloides stercoralis.
    2. Zoophilic nematode: Toxocara canis, toxocara cati, Angiostrongylus cantoniensis, Angiostrongylus costaricensis, Anisakis.
    3. Non-human nematode: Filarial species, Brugia pahangi, Brugia pate
  • Laboratory diagnosis of strongyloidiasis:
    • Eosinophilia and raised IgE levels.
    • Microscopic examination of the direct wet mount of the stool demonstrating rhabditiform larvae forms the definitive diagnosis
    • Stool culture and serological tests are also done
  • Treatment: Ivermectin is the preferred agent in the management of strongyloidiasis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Ancylostoma canium presents with creeping eruption. Cutaneous larva migrans or creeping eruption is caused by nematode larvae that infect by skin penetration.

 

Option B) Capillaria phillipinesis can also cause auto-infection. It commonly presents with severe diarrhea.

 

Option D) Enterobius vermicularis or pinworm infection presents as itching (pruritus) and restless sleep (due to nocturnal perianal or perineal pruritus)

 

Autoinfection: CHEST (Mnemonic)

  1. Cryptosporidium parvum
  2. H. nana larva
  3. Enterobius vermicularis
  4. Strongyloides
  5. Taenia solium

choices.text: End systolic volume and total peripheral resistance
End diastolic volume and pulse pressure
Stroke volume and total peripheral resistance
Stroke volume and end diastolic volume

questions.text: The Frank-Starling curve will relate these two parameters of the cardiac cycle:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stroke volume and end diastolic volume

 

  • According to Frank-Starling law, the energy of contraction of the heart will be proportional to the initial length of the cardiac muscle fiber.
  • For the heart, the length of the muscle fibers or the extent of the preload will be proportional to the end-diastolic volume.
  • The Frank-Starling curve will depict the relation between the stroke volume of the ventricles and the end-diastolic volume.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th edition, page no. 546

questions.text: A rape victim is examined in a hospital and a specimen from her vagina is subjected to staining by 10% HCl, potassium iodide, iodine and water. Dark brown rhombic-shaped crystals appear immediately. Which test was done?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Florence test

 

TESTS FOR SEMINAL STAINS

 

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

 

FLORENCE TEST

 

  • Stain used: 10% hydrochloric acid and Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water).
  • If semen is present, dark brown rhombic-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Acid Phosphatase test: Semen recovered from the vagina retains acid phosphatase concentrations up to 36 hours after its deposition. It is expressed in Bodansky units. If sperms are not found in the swab collected, on the basis of acid phosphatase enzyme present in semen is much higher concentration than other body fluids if the test is positive, it suggests that the semen is present.

 

Option C) Barberio test: When alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to semen, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are seen.

 

Option D) Creatine phosphokinase test: Spermatozoa contain high levels of creatine phosphokinase and can be demonstrated even in old stains after 6 months.

 

 

 

Barberio Test: Note the yellow, needle-shaped crystals of Spermine picrate

 

Ref: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, page no. 434-436

questions.text: A research team has isolated the enzyme DNA polymerase I from E. coli. A fragment of the enzyme is known as Klenow fragment, which lacks activity of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5’-3’ exonuclease

 

  • In bacteria, there are 5 polymerases.
  • Arthur Kornberg (Nobel prize, 1959) isolated the DNA polymerase I (Kornberg’s enzyme) from Escherichia coli.
  • It is a repair enzyme. It has both 3′ to 5′ and 5′ to 3′ exonuclease activities.
  • When 5′ to 3′ exonuclease domain is removed, the remaining fragment retains the polymerization and proofreading activities; it is then called the Klenow fragment.

questions.text: What alternative drug would you use for cardiac arrest if epinephrine is not effective?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amiodarone

 

  • Epinephrine and amiodarone are the two main drugs approved by the American Heart Association for the resuscitation of a cardiac arrest patient.
  • Dose of epinephrine = 1 mg every 3-5 min IV
  • Dose of Amiodarone = 300 mg IV bolus dose
  • Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic drug that is used to treat and prevent various types of arrhythmias.
  • For cardiac arrest, amiodarone is particularly recommended for ventricular fibrillation (VF) and pulseless ventricular tachycardia (VT) when initial defibrillation attempts have failed.
  • It acts by prolonging the action potential and refractory period in myocardial tissue, and it also has vasodilatory effects.
  • The initial recommended dose for cardiac arrest is 300 mg IV push.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Vasopressin.

 

  • Vasopressin is a synthetic peptide that stimulates V1 receptors, leading to vasoconstriction.
  • It was once considered as an alternative to epinephrine for cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), but more recent guidelines from organizations like the American Heart Association (AHA) have moved away from recommending its routine use in cardiac arrest.
  • This is due to a lack of evidence showing a significant improvement in survival to hospital discharge.

 

Option B) Atropine.

 

  • Atropine is an anticholinergic drug that blocks the effects of the vagus nerve on the heart.
  • It increases the heart rate and was previously used in the treatment of asystole and pulseless electrical activity (PEA) cardiac arrest.
  • However, more recent AHA guidelines no longer recommend atropine for routine use in these situations due to lack of evidence for its effectiveness.

 

Option D) Adenosine.

 

  • Adenosine is a drug that is primarily used to treat certain types of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT).
  • It works by slowing down the electrical activity in the heart, which can temporarily stop the heart, allowing it to "reset" itself to a normal rhythm.
  • While adenosine can be very effective for its indicated uses, it's not typically used in the setting of cardiac arrest.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation with a controlled ventricular rate. The medication charts reveal that he was taking digoxin, potassium chloride, clarithromycin, atenolol, and triamterene. Suspecting the symptoms to be due to digoxin overdose, plasma levels of digoxin were ordered. It was found that his blood levels of digoxin have increased significantly. Which of his medications is most likely responsible for this increase in digoxin levels?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clarithromycin

 

  • Clarithromycin is known to inhibit the cytochrome P450 system, which is involved in the metabolism of many drugs, including digoxin.
  • By inhibiting the metabolism of digoxin, clarithromycin can lead to elevated levels of digoxin in the blood, increasing the risk for digoxin toxicity.
  • Clarithromycin also acts as an inhibitor of the P-glycoprotein and can precipitate Digoxin toxicity.
  • P glycoproteins are drug efflux pumps in the intestine that lead to a decrease in the bioavailability of drugs.
  • Digoxin is one of the drugs that utilizes this mechanism for its metabolism.
  • Therefore, the drugs which inhibit the Pgp can lead to the increased plasma concentration of Digoxin and lead to its toxicity.
  • Other drugs that inhibit the Pgp include:
    • Amiodarone
    • Verapamil
    • Diltiazem
    • Itraconazole
    • Propafenone
    • Flecainide 
    • Quinidine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Potassium chloride. This medication primarily affects potassium levels and has no significant interaction with digoxin metabolism.

 

Option C) Atenolol. Atenolol, a beta-blocker, is not known to significantly interact with digoxin metabolism.

 

Option D) Triamterene. This diuretic medication primarily affects sodium and potassium levels and is not known to have a significant impact on digoxin metabolism.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented with increasing abdominal girth. On examination, shifting dullness was present and the liver span was less than 7cm. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes. What is the content of these inclusions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intermediate filaments

 

  • The clinical scenario given here describes alcoholic hepatitis. In this condition, there are intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions called Mallory Denk bodies and they contain intermediate filaments.
    1. Hepatocellular necrosis
    2. Mallory bodies or alcoholic hyaline
  • These are eosinophilic, intracytoplasmic inclusions found in swollen and ballooned hepatocytes.
  • They represent aggregates of cytoskeletal intermediate filaments (prekeratin).
  • They are best seen with connective tissue stains such as Masson's trichrome and chromophobe aniline blue, as well as immunoperoxidase methods.
  • Mallory bodies are highly suggestive of, but not specific for, alcoholic hepatitis, as they can be found in a variety of other conditions, including primary biliary cirrhosis, Indian childhood cirrhosis, cholestatic syndromes, Wilson's disease, intestinal bypass surgery, focal nodular hyperplasia, and hepatocellular carcinoma.
    1. Inflammatory response: primarily polymorphs with some scattered mononuclear cells.
    2. Fibrosis: Pericellular and perivenular fibrosis that appears web-like or chickenwire-like. This is also termed as creeping collagenosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female gave birth to a healthy male baby at 38 weeks via normal vaginal delivery. The delivery was uncomplicated. 24 hours later, the baby was brought to NICU with the complaints of high fever, lethargy and poor feeding. The baby was tachypneic and had tachycardia. Blood culture was sent which showed beta hemolytic colonies. These bacteria were showing positive CAMP test. Most probable organism is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) S. agalactiae

 

  • Term baby showing fever and poor feeding within 72 hours of birth is highly suggestive of neonatal sepsis.
  • The most common organism for neonatal sepsis worldwide is S. agalactiae.
  • It is a Group B Streptococci which is bacitracin resistant and forms mucoid, larger beta haemolytic colonies.
  • Lab diagnosis is done by following tests:
      1.  
  1. Hippurate hydrolysis test – positive
  2. CAMP test – positive
  3. Bacitracin – Resistant
  4. PYR test – negative

 

Other options:

 

Option A) S. pyogenes. Group A streptococci, bacitracin sensitive CAMP –ve, beta haemolytic pinpoint colonies.

 

Option B) S. aureus. Coagulase +ve, catalase +ve, golden yellow colonies.

 

Option C) S. pneumoniae. Optochin sensitive commensals of human respiratory tract.

 

Ref: Apurba S Sastry, 3rd edition, page no. 525

questions.text: Which compound among the options is predominantly responsible for the disinfectant quality to bleaching powder?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypochlorous acid

 

  • The primary reason for the disinfectant ability of bleaching powder stems from the activity of hypochlorous acid, which is responsible for its effectiveness (905 of total disinfection).
  • It surpasses hypochlorite ions in effectiveness by a factor of 70-80.

 

BLEACHING POWDER (CaOCl2)

 

2.5 gms of bleaching powder is sufficient to disinfect 1000L of water.

 

Mechanism of action:

 

  • CHLORINE + IMPURITIES → DESTRUCTION – Add some additional Cl2 [free residual Cl2]
  • Main disinfecting action of chlorine in water is due to HYPOCHLOROUS ACID [HOCL] [90% of disinfection] + Hypochlorite ions [10% of disinfection]

 

H2O + Cl → HCI + HOCI

 

HOCI → H + OCI

choices.text: Antagonize leukotriene D4 receptor

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with a long history of asthma is referred to pulmonologist. The physician decides to prescribe zileuton. The mechanism of action of this drug is to:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inhibits 5-lipoxygenase

 

  • 5-lipoxygenase is an enzyme that plays a role in the production of leukotrienes, which are inflammatory mediators that can contribute to the development and progression of asthma.
  • Zileuton inhibits 5-lipoxygenase, which helps to reduce the production of leukotrienes and the associated inflammation in the airways, making it a useful drug for the treatment of asthma.
  • Antagonizing leukotriene D4 receptor (option A) is the mechanism of action of drugs such as montelukast and zafirlukast, which are leukotriene receptor antagonists.
  • Inhibiting phosphodiesterase (option C) is the mechanism of action of drugs such as theophylline, which is a bronchodilator and anti-inflammatory agent.
  • Stimulating beta-2 receptors (option D) is the mechanism of action of drugs such as salbutamol and terbutaline, which are short-acting beta-2 agonists used as rescue inhalers for acute asthma exacerbations.

questions.text: What is the type of necrosis seen in the vessel wall of a patient with polyarteritis nodosa?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibrinoid necrosis

 

  • Immune responses that affect blood vessels, such in polyarteritis nodosa, typically display fibrinoid necrosis.
  • Grossly, PAN lesions appear as minute beaded nodules at the bifurcations and branching of vessel segments.
  • Antigen-antibody complexes accumulate in the blood arteries in several immunological diseases.
  • Complement activation brought on by these complexes causes type III hypersensitivity, which damages cells.
  • This leads to leakage of fibrin out of the blood vessel, giving a pinkish appearance around the blood vessels.
  • Fibrinoid necrosis is characterized by deposition of fibrin-like material which has the staining properties of fibrin.
  • It is encountered in various examples of immunologic tissue injury (e.g., in immune complex vasculitis, autoimmune diseases, Arthus reaction etc.), arterioles in hypertension, peptic ulcer etc.

 

 

 

  • Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in the following conditions:
    • SLE
    • Libman-sacks endocarditis
    • Arthus reaction
    • Serum sickness
    • Polyarteritis nodosa
    • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
    • Malignant hypertension

choices.text: Enterotoxin of Staphylococcus
Emetic toxin of B. cereus
Verocytotoxin from E. coli
Shiga toxin from Shigella

questions.text: A group of 20 friends kept partying till late at night. Two of them ate pastries from outside. They present with nausea and vomiting in the early morning. What is the most likely causative agent implicated?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enterotoxin of Staphylococcus

 

  • The most likely causative agent in the given scenario is enterotoxin of Staphylococcus aureus.
  • It causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food.
  • The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches.
  • Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhea.
  • Food poisoning is caused by enterotoxin produced by S. aureus.
  • It is a preformed toxin that is relatively heat stable while most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile.
  • It stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting center of the brain and also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity.
  • Eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known of which is Type A toxin is responsible for most cases.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Emetic toxin of B. cereus. Food poisoning after consumption of fried rice or Chinese street food is strongly suggestive of Bacillus cereus (Serotypes 1, 3, 5). Two mechanisms of action have been described for the enterotoxin of B. cereus, one involving stimulation of the cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) system and the other independent of it. Food poisoning after eating food contaminated with Bacillus cereus is of two types, namely diarrheal type and emetic type, caused by an enterotoxin and an emetic toxin respectively.

choices.text: Contact with soil

questions.text: Which of these options is not a means of directly transmitting communicable diseases?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Droplet nuclei

 

  • Airborne transmission by droplet nuclei is a method of indirect transmission of diseases.
  • Droplet nuclei are tiny particles of size 1-5 microns range that may be formed by either due to evaporation of droplets coughed or sneezed into the air or are formed from aerosols.
  • These droplet nuclei remain airborne for long periods of time and can transmit diseases like tuberculosis, influenza, chickenpox, measles, Q fever and other respiratory infections.
  • Droplet transmission, vertical transmission, and contact with soil are methods of direct transmission of diseases.

choices.text: a, b, c

questions.text:
A patient came to the surgical OPD with complaints of lower limb pain. After eliciting complete history, the surgeon considers the first differential to be intermittent claudication due to arterial disorder. Which of the following features would have prompted him to consider this differential?

 

 

  1. Brought on by walking
  2. Present on taking first step
  3. Relieved on resting for 5 mins
  4. Distance that patient is able to walk without stopping greatly varying every day
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a, c

 

  • Intermittent claudication is classically described as debilitating cramp like pain in the muscles due to anaerobic muscle metabolism.
  • The characteristic features of intermittent claudication are as follows:
    • Brought on by walking (option a)
    • Not present on taking the first step (unlike osteoarthritis) (option b)
    • Relieved by rest in both the standing and sitting positions, usually within 5 minutes (Option c) (unlike nerve compression from a lumbar intervertebral disc prolapse or osteoarthritis of the spine or spinal stenosis, which are typically relieved only when resting in the sitting position for longer than 5 minutes).
    • The distance that a patient is able to walk without stopping varies (claudication distance) only slightly from day to day (Option d). 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The muscle group affected by claudication is classically one anatomical level below the level of arterial disease and is usually felt in the posterior calf as the superficial femoral artery is the most commonly affected artery (70% of cases).
  • Aortoiliac disease (30% of cases) may cause thigh or buttock claudication. Leriche’s syndrome is buttock claudication combined with sexual impotence, which is secondary to arterial insufficiency.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page no. 998

choices.text: To reapply the patch with another adhesive
To apply a new patch
To apply a new patch and use a condom for 1 week
To remove the patch and use a condom till her next period

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman has been using the transdermal patch as a contraceptive method. She visits the OPD with the complaint that the patch was partially detached for more than a day. What will you advise her?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To apply a new patch and use a condom for 1 week

 

  • If the patch was detached for less than 24 h, the same patch can be reattached or a replaced with a new one.
  • If a patch is partially or completely detached for more than one day (24 hours or more)

 

OR

 

If the woman is not sure how long the patch has been detached, she may not be protected from pregnancy. She should stop the current contraceptive cycle and start a new cycle immediately by applying a new patch. Back-up contraception, such as a condom, spermicide, or diaphragm, must be used for the first week of the new cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Management of a detached transdermal contraceptive patch:
    • If the patch was detached for less than 24 h, the same patch can be reattached or a replaced with a new one.
    • If a patch is partially or completely detached for more than one day (24 hours or more)

 

OR

 

If the woman is not sure how long the patch has been detached, she may not be protected from pregnancy. She should stop the current contraceptive cycle and start a new cycle immediately by applying a new patch. Back-up contraception, such as a condom, spermicide, or diaphragm, must be used for the first week of the new cycle.

 

Ref: https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2011/021180s038lbl.pdf

choices.text: α-Glucosidase inhibitors may decrease levels of sulfonylureas
Simultaneous treatment with bile acid resins and antacids should be avoided
These agents should not be used in individuals with inflammatory bowel disease
These agents should not be used in individuals with serum creatinine >2mg/dL

questions.text: All of the following are true about α-Glucosidase inhibitors, except
questions.solution:
Ans. A) α-Glucosidase inhibitors may decrease levels of sulfonylureas

 

  • α-Glucosidase inhibitors may increase levels of sulfonylureas and increase the incidence of hypoglycemia.
  • Simultaneous treatment with bile acid resins and antacids should be avoided.
  • These agents should not be used in individuals with inflammatory bowel disease, gastroparesis, or a serum creatinine >177 μmol/L (2 mg/dL).
  • This class of agents is not as potent as other oral agents in lowering the HbA1c but is unique because it reduces the postprandial glucose rise.

 

Ref: Harrison’s 21st edition, page no. 3112

choices.text: Spironolactone is a potassium sparing drug.
Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic.
Thiazides act by inhibiting Na-K-2Cl co-transporter.
Acetazolamide inhibits carbonic anhydrase enzyme.

questions.text: All the following are true regarding diuretics except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Thiazides act by inhibiting Na-K-2Cl co-transporter

 

  • Na-K-2Cl transporter is present in ascending limb of loop of Henle and is inhibited by loop diuretics like furosemide.
  • Thiazides act by inhibiting Na-Cl transporter in early distal tubules.

choices.text: Lateral to the second upper molar tooth
Lateral to the lingual frenulum
In the floor of the mouth
In the mandibular foramen

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes because of 2 weeks history of painful swelling on right side of face. USG shows a stone in a duct that runs anterior to the masseter muscle and passes through the buccinator muscle. Sialendoscopy is performed to remove the stone. At which of the following sites is the endoscope most likely to be inserted during the procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lateral to the second upper molar tooth

 

  • The location of the stone is in the Stenson’s duct (parotid duct).
  • It emerges from the anterior edge of the parotid gland turns medically at the anterior edge of the masseter muscle and after piercing through the buccinator muscle, enters the oral cavity lateral to the second upper molar.
  • This is the correct location for sialendoscopy when addressing issues with the parotid duct, aligning with the ultrasound findings.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Lateral to the lingual frenulum. This is the location of the submandibular gland duct, or Wharton's duct, which opens at the sublingual caruncle by the lingual frenulum.

 

Option C) Into the floor of the mouth. While the floor of the mouth is the location for the openings of both the sublingual glands and the submandibular glands, it is not the correct site for a parotid duct stone.

 

Option D) Into the mandibular foramen. The mandibular foramen is an opening on the internal surface of the ramus of the mandible for the mandibular nerve and vessels; it is not related to the salivary glands or ducts and would not be a site for sialendoscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a sialendoscopy procedure to remove a stone from the parotid duct, the endoscope is most likely to be inserted lateral to the second upper molar tooth, which is where the parotid duct opens into the oral cavity after passing through the buccinator muscle.

choices.text: Repeat pap smear

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady complains of post-coital bleeding. She has a positive pap smear. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Colposcopy-directed biopsy

 

  • A positive pap smear means that the cytology is showing some abnormality (Epithelial or Glandular cell abnormalities).
  • This should be followed up by a colposcopy and directed biopsy.
  • Colposcopy is done which gives a magnified view of the cervix.
  • During colposcopy, Ried’s index or Swede’s scoring is done to determine the severity of the visible pathology.
  • Cervical biopsy is taken from the acetowhite areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Cone Biopsy.

 

  •  
  • Also called Conization
  • Usually in CIN 2/3, LLETZ (large loop excision of the transformation zone is preferred) but sometimes, conization needs to be done in the following situations:
    • Unsatisfactory colposcopic findings. The entire margins of the lesion are not visualized.
    • Inconsistent findings: Colposcopic, cytology and directed biopsy.
    • Positive endocervical curettage
    • When biopsy cannot rule out invasive cancer from CIS or microinvasion.

 

Option C) Repeat Pap smear. This is not preferred in this scenario as the exact abnormality is not mentioned. In a low grade squamous intra-epithelial lesion (LSIL), if the HPV is negative, a repeat pap smear with HPV testing can be advised.

 

Option D) A hysterectomy is never indicated for only an abnormal pap smear. It is indicated only if the colposcopic directed biopsy shows:

 

  •  
  • CIN lesion associated with other gynecologic problems such as prolapse, fibroid, pelvic inflammatory disease or endometriosis.
  • Persistent dyskaryotic smear even with treatment.
  • High grade CIN in elderly women.
  •  Patients with poor compliance for follow up.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A positive pap smear should be followed by a colposcopy and a colposcopic directed cervical biopsy from abnormal areas.

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition, Page no. 329

choices.text: The diagnosis based on the clinical feature is Klippel Feil Syndrome
Pathology is due to defective somite development between 3rd and 8th week of foetal development
Torticollis is a key finding in this syndrome
Triad of this disease includes low posterior hair line, short neck and limitations of neck movement

questions.text: A mother brings her child with complaints of limited neck movements. On examination, the following findings were noted. An X-ray reveals the pathology of non-segmentation of the cervical vertebra. All of the following are true regarding the findings except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Torticollis is a key finding in this syndrome

 

  • In Klippel Feil syndrome, there is congenital short and stiff neck due to fused or deformed cervical vertebrae.
  • It occurs due to failure of normal segmentation of cervical vertebra somite between 3rd and 8th week of foetal development
  • Characterized by Feil’s Triad: low posterior hair line, short neck, limitations of head and neck movement.

 

Other options:

 

Option A), B) and D) are true statements regarding Klippel Feil Syndrome.

questions.text: A 9-year-old patient is brought to the emergency department with a supracondylar humerus fracture following a fall from a tree. After the injury, the patient is unable to flex the interphalangeal joint of the thumb on the affected side. Which nerve is most likely injured in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) AIN (Anterior Interosseous Nerve)

 

  • Supracondylar humerus fracture is a common pediatric elbow fracture.
  • The primary muscle responsible for flexing the interphalangeal joint of the thumb is the Flexor Pollicis Longus (FPL). It is innervated by the Anterior Interosseous Nerve (AIN).
  • The AIN is a pure motor branch of the Median Nerve. It branches off the median nerve in the forearm and supplies the FPL, the flexor digitorum profundus to the index and middle fingers, and the pronator quadratus.
  • Injury to the AIN can result in weakness or paralysis of these muscles, leading to difficulty in flexing the thumb's interphalangeal joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median nerve: The median nerve innervates the flexor pollicis longus muscle, which is responsible for flexing the interphalangeal joint of the thumb. Damage to the median nerve can result in weakness or paralysis of this muscle and, consequently, an inability to flex the thumb's interphalangeal joint. The AIN is a branch of the median nerve. If the main median nerve is injured proximally (e.g., at the level of a supracondylar fracture), the AIN would also be affected, leading to inability to flex the IP joint of the thumb.

 

Option B. Superficial branch of ulnar nerve: The superficial branch of the ulnar nerve primarily innervates the skin of the ulnar (medial) side of the hand. It is not responsible for thumb flexion. 

 

Option D. PIN (Posterior Interosseous Nerve): The posterior interosseous nerve is a branch of the radial nerve that primarily innervates the extensor muscles of the forearm and hand. It is not involved in thumb flexion. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • A complete median nerve injury would include AIN palsy, a supracondylar humerus fracture specifically has a known association with AIN palsy, often as an isolated motor deficit of the median nerve.
  • The described deficit (inability to flex the IP joint of the thumb) is the classic presentation of an AIN injury affecting the FPL.
  • If it were a complete median nerve injury, an additional sensory deficit in the median nerve distribution (thumb, index, middle, radial half of ring finger) and weakness of other median-innervated muscles (e.g., thenar muscles for thumb abduction and opposition, forearm pronators) is also seen.
  • Since the question only specifies the inability to flex the IP joint of the thumb, therefore AIN the most likely nerve injured.

choices.text: Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic liver disease presents with abdominal distension, jaundice, and pruritus. Ascitic fluid analysis revealed neutrophil count > 650 per cubic mm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis

 

  • Ascitic fluid neutrophil > 250 cells/mm3 is suggestive of SBP which is condition that occurs due to translocation of gut bacteria in patients with cirrhosis.
  • Most commonly caused by GNB (E. coli).
  • Treatment with 3rd generation cephalosporin along with albumin (Reduces AKI).
  • Long term prophylaxis indicated if prior history of SBP.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Malignant ascites presents with lymphocytic pleocytosis which presents with peritoneal thickening, low SAAG and high protein ascites.

 

Option C) Tubercular ascites is lymphocytic with peritoneal tubercles, omental thickening and elevated ADA levels.

 

Option D) Intestinal obstruction presents with constipation, abdominal pain and vomiting. Treatment is initially conservative with enteral rest, decompression with NG tube.

 

Ref: Harrison, Cirrhosis, Chapter 344

questions.text: A defect in which of the following forms the structure marked below as A?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fascia transversalis

 

  • Marked structure is the deep inguinal ring, formed by a defect in fascia transversalis.
  • The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia present 1 cm above the inguinal ligament, midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis.
  • An indirect inguinal hernia arises through the deep inguinal ring, lateral to the inferior epigastric vessel.

 

 

 

 

  • The fascia transversalis is a thin aponeurotic membrane which lies between the inner surface of the transversus abdominis muscle and the parietal peritoneum.
  • Origin and Coverage: It covers the entire inner surface of the abdominal wall and is continuous with the iliac and pelvic fasciae.
  • Relation: Hernias that penetrate the fascia transversalis in the groin region are called direct inguinal hernias.

 

Let's delve into each of these structures, which are important components of the abdominal wall and its lining:

 

Option A) Internal Oblique.

 

  • The internal oblique muscle is one of the three major muscles of the lateral abdominal wall. It lies just deep to the external oblique and superficial to the transversus abdominis.
  • Origin and Insertion: It originates from the lumbar fascia, anterior two-thirds of the iliac crest, and lateral half of the inguinal ligament. It inserts into the lower ribs, linea alba, and the pubic bone.
  • Innervation: It is innervated by the lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and the first lumbar nerve.

 

Option B) External Oblique.

 

  • The external oblique is the most superficial of the three flat muscles of the lateral abdominal wall.
  • Origin and Insertion: It originates from the outer surfaces of the 5th to 12th ribs and inserts into the linea alba, pubic tubercle, and anterior half of the iliac crest.
  • Innervation: Like the internal oblique, it's innervated by the lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and the first lumbar nerve.

 

Option C) Parietal Peritoneum.

 

  • The parietal peritoneum is the outer layer of the peritoneum that lines the internal surface of the abdominal wall.
  • Composition: It consists of a single layer of squamous epithelial cells (mesothelium) and its underlying connective tissue.
  • Innervation: The parietal peritoneum overlying the anterior abdominal wall is primarily innervated by the lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and the first lumbar nerve.

choices.text: The statement A is true, the statement B is false
The statement A is false, the statement B is true
Both the statements A and B are true
Both the statements A and B are false

questions.text:
Statement A: The filtration fraction will be decreased by the constriction of the afferent arteriole.

 

Statement B: The dilation of the afferent arteriole will increase the renal blood flow, but decreases the glomerular filtration rate.

 

Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Both the statements A and B are false

 

  • The constriction of the afferent arteriole will decrease the renal blood flow, thereby decreasing the glomerular filtration rate, both the GFR and RPF are decreasing hence the Filtration fraction remains the same.
  • The dilation of the afferent arterioles of the glomerulus will increase the renal blood flow, which results in increased glomerular filtration rate.
  • Both the renal blood flow and the glomerular filtration rate will be increased by the dilation of the afferent arterioles.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition, page no. 498

choices.text: Oral Submucous Fibrosis

questions.text: A chronic tobacco user presents with intolerance to spicy food, soreness of the mouth, and restricted mouth opening. On examination, the oral mucosa appears pale and is characterized by fibrotic bands. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral Submucous Fibrosis

 

  • Oral Submucous Fibrosis is strongly associated with chronic tobacco use, especially chewing tobacco.
  • It presents with progressive fibrosis of the submucosal tissues, leading to stiffness of the oral mucosa, restricted mouth opening, and intolerance to spicy food.
  • The mucosa often appears pale and fibrotic, as described in the patient.
  • Oral Submucous Fibrosis (OSF) is a chronic insidious process characterized by juxta epithelial deposition of fibrous tissue in the oral cavity and pharynx.
  • Aetiology:
  1. Tobacco chewing
  2. Areca nut chewing
  3. Alcohol
  4. Nutritional deficiency
  5. Immune reaction to arecoline in areca nut
  6. Multifactorial
  • Clinical Features:
  1. Intolerance to chillies and spicy food.
  2. Soreness of mouth with constant burning sensation worsens enduring meals particularly of pungent spicy type.
  3. Repeated vesicular eruption on the palate and pillars.
  4. Difficulty to open the mouth fully.
  5. Difficulty to protrude the tongue.
  • Findings:
  1. Changes of submucous fibrosis are mostly marked over
  1. Soft Palate
  2. Faucial Pillars
  3. Buccal Mucosa
  1. Patchy redness of mucous membrane with formation of vesicles which rupture to form superficial ulcers
  2. Fibrosis in the submucosal layers, there is blanching of mucosa with loss of suppleness
  3. Fibrotic bands can be seen and felt in the affected areas.
  4. Fibrosis and scarring has also been demonstrated in the underlying muscle leading to further restrictive mobility of soft palate, tongue and jaw.
  5. Trismus is progressive

 

 

  • Treatment:
  1. Topical injection of steroids into the affected area. It may be combined with hyaluronidase.
  2. Avoid irritant factors like pan, tobacco, areca nut etc
  3. Treatment of nutritional deficiency
  4. Jaw opening exercises
  5. Surgical treatment: Simple release of fibrosis and skin grafting

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Leukoplakia refers to white patches or plaques on the oral mucosa that cannot be rubbed off and cannot be attributed to any other cause. While it is associated with tobacco use, it does not typically cause restricted mouth opening or the soreness described in the patient.

 

Option C) Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin and mucous membranes. In the mouth, it usually presents as lace-like white patches (Wickham's striae) or red, swollen tissues. It does not typically result in restricted mouth opening.

 

Option D) Mucositis is an inflammation of the mucous membranes in the mouth, often as a side effect of chemotherapy or radiation therapy. It can cause soreness and ulceration but does not usually lead to fibrosis or restricted mouth opening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diagnose Oral Submucous Fibrosis in patients with a history of chronic tobacco use presenting with intolerance to spicy food, soreness of the mouth, restricted mouth opening, and pale, fibrotic oral mucosa.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, page no. 220-222

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of anaemia/thrombocytopenia and also bone pain. O/E, hepatosplenomegaly was observed, and light microscopy reveals crumpled tissue paper appearance. The enzyme defect is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucocerebrosidase

 

GAUCHER’S DISEASE

 

  • Most common Lysosomal Storage Disorder due to Glucocerebrosidase defect → accumulation of glucocerebroside in lysosomes.
  • C/F: No cherry red spot in the macula, no mental deterioration (Type I), Haematological features: Pancytopenia, bleeding manifestation, Hepatosplenomegaly, Bone Pain and Pathological Fractures of long bones
  • Bone Marrow Biopsy: Gaucher cell with Wrinkled paper appearance/crumpled tissue paper appearance.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Sphingomyelinase. Niemann-Pick disease

 

Option C) Hexosaminidase A. Tay Sach’s disease

 

Option D) Beta-galactosidase. Generalized gangliosidosis

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan, 9th edition, page no. 260, 261

questions.text: Below is an electron microscopy depiction of a cellular structure. Determine the type of cell being depicted:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hairy cell

 

  • Hairy cells are seen in Hairy cell leukemia.
  • It is a B-cell tumour.
  • Peripheral smear shows pancytopenia; hairy cells.
  • Flow cytometry shows CD11/25/103 + cells. Annexin-A is the best marker.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Target cell can be seen in thalassemia, hepatic disease with jaundice, hemoglobin C disorders, and the post splenectomy state.

 

 

Option C) Gaucher cell is found in Gaucher’s disease which occurs due to absence of beta glucocerebrosidase enzyme.

 

 

Option D) Sickle cells are seen in sickle cell anemia. HbS has altered solubility and high chance of polymer formation especially with dehydration or hypoxemia causing alteration in shape. On rehydration, it is reversible.

questions.text: A female patient who is from the north-eastern part of the country, came to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling of the upper limb. She has a history of coronary artery disease for which she underwent percutaneous coronary intervention. On examination, the limbs are more swollen proximally than distally. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Night blood test for worms

 

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of filariasis.
  • The next best step would be to test the night blood for worms since the filarial species is nocturnally periodic (between 10 pm and 4 am) in India.

questions.text: A poor farmer with a history of successive crop failure develops progressive spastic paraparesis, signs of upper motor neuron paralysis, and gait instability. Name the toxin responsible for this condition.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine

 

  • Given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of neurolathyrism, for which the toxin responsible is beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine.

 

FOOD ADULTERATION DISEASES

 

 

 

  • Lathyrism is of two types:
    • Neurolathyrism: In human beings
    • Osteolathyrism: In animals
    • Neurolathyrism is caused by eating the pulse ‘Khesari Dal (Lathyrus sativus)’. Diets containing over 30% of this dal consumed over a period of 2-6 months result in neurolathyrism.
    • Lathyrism affects 15-45 years of age.
    • Toxin: present in lathyrus seeds is ‘Beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA)’Q
  • It manifests as following stages:
    • Latent stage
    • No-stick stage
    • One-stick stage
    • Two-stick stage
    • Crawler stage
  • Interventions for prevention and control of Lathyrism:
    • Vitamin C
    • Banning the crop
    • Removal of toxin: Steeping method and Parboiling
    • Education
    • Genetic approach
    • Socio-economic changes

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was undergoing a routine check-up when the radiologist noticed gallstones on USG. However, the patient says that there have been no complaints so far and she is asymptomatic. The stone measures 3 cms. What will be your treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lap cholecystectomy

 

  • Asymptomatic gallstones do not need intervention however, prophylactic cholecystectomy may be performed for asymptomatic cholelithiasis in the following situations:
    • Large (>3 cm) gallstones;
    • Choledocholithiasis;
    • Chronic haemolytic conditions (sickle cell disease, hereditary spherocytosis);
    • Gallbladder polyps >1 cm in diameter;
    • Suspicion/risk of malignancy (anomalous pancreatic ductal drainage);
    • Calcification of the wall (porcelain gallbladder);
    • Some ethnic groups or subjects living in areas with a high prevalence of gallbladder cancer associated with gallstones (some parts of northern India, Native Americans, Mexican Americans, Colombia, Chile, Bolivia);
    • Transplant patients (during transplantation);
    • Bariatric surgery.

 

Ref: Bailey, 28th Edition, Page no. 1244

questions.text: Mr. Raj Kumar, a 60-year-old male, has been diagnosed with terminal pancreatic cancer and is experiencing severe pain that is not adequately controlled with oral medications. His physician wants to switch him to a transdermal opioid for more consistent pain control. Which of the following opioids would be the best choice for this patient’s malignancy-associated pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fentanyl

 

  • Fentanyl is a potent synthetic opioid that is commonly used by transdermal route for the treatment of chronic pain, particularly in cases of malignancy-associated pain.
  • It is highly lipophilic and can penetrate the skin and subcutaneous tissue to reach the systemic circulation, providing sustained analgesia over a period of 72 hours or longer.
  • Morphine, codeine, and oxycodone are also commonly used opioids for pain management, but are typically administered orally or by injection, rather than transdermally.

choices.text: HIV DNA PCR
Cord blood ELISA

questions.text: What is the diagnostic test of choice for HIV in a baby born to an HIV-infected mother?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HIV DNA PCR

 

  • Maternal antibodies transferred passively to the infant may persist 9-18 months and hence ELISA/antibody tests positivity would indicate possible exposure to HIV.
  • Currently, NACO recommends HIV-TNA PCR (Total nucleic acid = pro-viral DNA + RNA) which has Sensitivity of 99% and Specificity of 98% in infants < 18 months of age.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Cord blood ELISA. DBS (Dried blood sample) is recommended and not CORD BLOOD (as it contains maternal blood contamination).

 

Option C) Western blot is not recommended by NACO for the diagnosis of HIV.

 

Option D) Third generation ELISA based test detects antibodies, however, maternal transmission occurs in infants trans placentally and hence cannot help in diagnosis of active disease.

 

Ref: NACO 2021 HIV Care and treatment guidelines, Page no. 185

questions.text: Which of the following drug can be used for treatment of euvolemic hyponatremia in patient with advanced congestive heart failure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tolvaptan 

 

  • The most common cause of euvolemic hyponatremia is SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone). Thus, the question is asking about the drug for SIADH in patients with cardiac failure.
  • Tolvaptan is an orally active nonpeptide vasopressin V2 receptor antagonist introduced for the correction of water retention and hyponatremia occurring in ‘syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion’ (SIADH) as well as in advanced CHF.
  • Tolvaptan can afford short-term improvement by increasing water excretion, restoring serum Na+ and relieving dyspnoea. However, no long-term benefits have been noted.

questions.text: A publicity campaign carried out deliberately to promote the product in favorable note, so that people accept the product without exploring further is known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Propaganda

 

  • When persuasive communication is deliberately employed to manipulate feelings, attitudes, and beliefs, it becomes “propaganda” or “brain washing”.
  • In Health propaganda, there is spread of systemized doctrine, the knowledge is instilled in minds of people and its spoon-fed (Passive reception).
  • It appeals to emotions of people and leads to Reflexive behaviour.
  • Persuasion is “a conscious attempt by one individual to change or influence the general beliefs, understanding, values and behavior of another individual or group of individuals in some desired way”.

 

Ref: Park, 26th edition, page no. 953

choices.text: Inj. Oxytocin 20 IU in RL

questions.text: A 30-year-old G2 delivers a 3.5 kg baby by forceps. 2 hours following delivery, the nurse checks her vital signs, and her PR is 120 bpm and BP is 90/60 mmHg. There is minimal vaginal bleeding, and the uterus is well contracted but appears deviated to one side. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urgent ultrasound

 

  • As there is no obvious bleeding and the patient is in shock, the next best step would be to do an urgent ultrasound to rule out a broad ligament (supra-levator) hematoma.
  • With a supra-levator extension, the hematoma extends upward in the paravaginal space and between the leaves of the broad ligament. The hematoma may escape detection until it can be felt on abdominal palpation or until hypovolemia develops. Imaging with sonography or computed tomographic scanning may be useful.
  • Treatment of a supra-levator hematoma: Laparotomy with evacuation. Very often a hysterectomy may be required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A broad ligament hematoma should be suspected in a patient following delivery who is in shock with no obvious excessive bleeding and where the uterus appears well contracted.

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no. 1923

questions.text: A patient undergoes right heart catheterization for evaluation of pulmonary hypertension. What is the cutoff beyond which pulmonary hypertension can be diagnosed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) >20mmHg

 

  • Pulmonary hypertension is defined as mPAP (Mean pulmonary artery pressure) >20mmHg.

 

Ref: Harrison, 21st Edition, Pulmonary Hypertension, Chapter 283, Figure 283-2; ESC guidelines on pulmonary Hypertension 2022

questions.text: A patient with deep vein thrombosis was started on a new drug. After 2 days, he presented with the given finding. Which of the following drugs is implicated in causing the above condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Warfarin

 

  • The figure shows clinical picture of dermal vascular necrosis, also known as ‘purple toe syndrome’.
  • It is an early adverse effect of warfarin.
  • It is seen in patients with genetic protein C deficiency.

 

DERMAL VASCULAR NECROSIS

 

  • Warfarin-induced dermal vascular necrosis is a rare complication of warfarin therapy.
  • It characterized by the development of painful skin lesions in patients taking warfarin.
  • It is thought to be caused by a transient hypercoagulable state resulting from a rapid reduction in protein C levels in patients with underlying protein C deficiency or other risk factors.
  • The lesions typically occur in areas with a high concentration of adipose tissue, such as the breasts, thighs, and buttocks.
  • The initial symptoms include red or purple spots on the skin that can quickly progress to painful, necrotic lesions with a central blister or eschar.
  • The diagnosis is usually made clinically based on the characteristic appearance of the lesions and the patient's history of warfarin therapy.
  • The treatment of dermal vascular necrosis involves stopping warfarin and initiating alternative anticoagulant therapy, such as heparin or low molecular weight heparin.
  • In severe cases, surgical intervention may be necessary to remove the necrotic tissue and prevent further damage.

choices.text: Ampulla of Vater
Ligament of Treitz
Superior duodenal flexure

questions.text: A 35-year-old man came with complaints of dark-colored stools to the OPD. After undergoing endoscopy, the patient was diagnosed with an upper GI bleed. Which of the following structures is used as a demarcation point to differentiate it from a lower GI bleed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ligament of Treitz

 

  • The ligament of Treitz is used as the demarcation point to differentiate between upper gastrointestinal bleeding and lower gastrointestinal bleeding.
  • It is a part of the duodenojejunal junction.
  • Upper GI bleeding refers to bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz, and lower Gl bleeding refers to bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Ampulla of Vater. The ampulla of Vater is the point where the pancreatic duct and common bile duct converge and enter the second part of the duodenum. It is an essential structure for the drainage of both bile and pancreatic enzymes into the duodenum. It is not used as a demarcation point for differentiating between upper and lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

 

Option C) Superior duodenal flexure. The superior duodenal flexure is the bend in the duodenum as it transitions from the first part (horizontal) to the second part (descending).

 

Option D) Ileocecal junction. The ileocecal junction is the point where the ileum meets the cecum. The ileocecal valve is present here, preventing the reflux of colonic contents into the ileum. While it's an important anatomical landmark in the gastrointestinal tract, it's not used as the demarcation point for differentiating between upper and lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

choices.text: Full course of tetanus vaccination
Single dose tetanus toxoid
Tetanus toxoid + immunoglobulin
No vaccination needed

questions.text: A patient arrives with a clean-cut injury, no lacerations. He reports receiving his last tetanus vaccination approximately a decade ago. What would be the recommended course of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Single dose tetanus toxoid

 

  • An individual injection of tetanus toxoid is administered since the wound is sterile, and the previous dose was taken over a decade ago.

choices.text: USG of neck

questions.text: A 45-year-old male living in a high-altitude region presents with a slow growing neck swelling in front of sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle. Examination reveals it to be firm, rubbery, with lateral mobility alone. The swelling is pulsatile. Which of these is not performed in the management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) FNAC

 

  • Swelling is likely to be a Carotid body tumor, for which both FNAC and core biopsy are contra-indicated.
  • Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC) is contraindicated in Carotid body tumors due to the risk of bleeding and potential for seeding tumor cells. This procedure is not performed for these tumors.
  • Let's evaluate all the options to determine which is not performed in the management of a slow-growing neck swelling suggestive of a Carotid body tumor:

 

Option A) USG of neck. Ultrasonography (USG) of the neck is a common initial imaging modality used to evaluate neck masses. It can provide information about the nature, size, and relation to adjacent structures of the swelling.

 

Option B) CT Angiogram. A CT angiogram is an essential diagnostic tool for Carotid body tumors as it can help delineate the vascular anatomy, splaying of the carotid bifurcation (Lyre sign), and relationship of the tumor to the carotid vessels.

 

Option D) Excision. Surgical excision is the treatment of choice for Carotid body tumors, particularly in cases where the tumor is resectable. The Shamblin classification helps determine the surgical approach and the extent of resection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The management of a Carotid body tumor involves imaging studies such as USG and CT angiogram to evaluate the lesion and plan treatment, but FNAC is contraindicated due to the risk of bleeding and tumor cell dissemination.
  • Surgical excision is the definitive treatment, tailored according to the tumor’s classification and involvement with carotid vessels.

choices.text: Tuberculosis with tubo-ovarian mass

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents with a history of low-grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain and amenorrhea for six months. On examination, a pelvic mass is felt on the left side and signs of ascites are positive. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tuberculosis with tubo-ovarian mass

 

  • This is the most likely diagnosis in view of the following points:
    • Age
    • Symptoms: low grade fever, weight loss, pain and amenorrhoea
    • Adnexal mass with ascites

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Ovarian malignancy may present with weight loss, ascites and a pelvic mass. But a young age and amenorrhea do not go in favor of ovarian malignancy.

 

Option C) Ectopic pregnancy will be an acute presentation and will not present with fever/ weight loss.

 

Option D) Submucous fibroid presents with menorrhagia/ inter-menstrual bleeding and the uterus will be uniformly enlarged. There will not be any pelvic mass. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Genital TB presents commonly in young women.
  • It primarily affects the fallopian tubes (most common) and the uterus.
  • Common symptoms include fever, weight loss, abdominal pain and menstrual symptoms (hypomenorrhea and amenorrhea).
  • Genital TB also commonly presents as infertility.

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition, Page no. 141

choices.text: Uterine artery embolization

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes with complaints of menorrhagia for the past 3 months. The duration and regularity of her menstrual cycles are normal. Non-hormonal management has been tried without success. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hormonal therapy

 

  • Hormonal therapy is the next best management modality. This includes combined oral contraceptive pills or even progesterone only devices like the LND-IUS.
  • First line management includes non-hormonal treatment like NSAIDs and Tranexamic acid.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Surgical management is the last option.
  • Surgical options include endometrial ablation (like TCRE), uterine artery embolization or hysterectomy. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In menorrhagia, the first line treatment is usually NSAIDs and antifibrinolytics (like tranexamic acid).
  • 2nd line management of menorrhagia includes hormonal treatment like combined OCPs or LNG-IUD.

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition, Page no. 197

questions.text: A newborn is brought with evisceration of bowel loops from a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gastroschisis

 

  • The most probable diagnosis for the evisceration of bowel loops, coming out of a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus is gastroschisis.
  • It occurs when there is a failure in the closure of the body wall in the abdominal region.
  • The defects seen in the ventral body wall include:

 

 

  • Gastroschisis is a congenital birth defect characterized by a defect in the abdominal wall, usually to the right of the umbilicus, which leads to the evisceration of the bowel loops which are not covered by a sac and are exposed to the external environment.
  • The affected bowel loops can be damaged by exposure to amniotic fluid.
  • Omphalocele: The bowel loops fail to return from the physiologic umbilical hernia. Since the umbilicus is covered by a reflection of the amnion, the omphalocele is also covered by amnion.
  • Congenital umbilical hernia: Umbilical hernia is a protrusion of the abdominal contents through a weakness in the umbilical ring, and ectopia vesicae is a rare congenital anomaly in which the urinary bladder is located outside the abdominal cavity.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Umbilical hernia. In case of umbilical hernia, we do not usually see content of bowel coming out. Umbilical hernia is a cystic swelling which regresess when the baby is sleeping & appears during crying. No treatment is required for such condition.

 

Option D) Ectopia vesicae is a rare congenital malformation where the urinary bladder is located outside the lower abdominal wall. This condition is often associated with other abnormalities of the urinary tract and reproductive system. Ectopia vesicae is typically noticed at birth, and its severity can vary depending on the specific case.

Ans. C) Bilateral choanal atresia and McGovern’s nipple

  • If the child doesn’t have any other serious medical problems Operative intervention is considered.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Tracheoesophageal fistula and Tracheostomy and Option B) Tracheoesophageal fistula and McGovern’s nipple presents with immediate features of coughing during feeding not with features of cyclical cyanosis.

 

Option D) Bilateral choanal atresia and Tracheostomy. The initial management of Bilateral choanal atresia is McGovern’s nipple not the Tracheostomy.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No. 8616-8618

questions.text: Antibiotic used for ESBL [Extended spectrum β lactamase] producing Klebsiella infection is
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Meropenem

 

  • Extended-spectrum β-lactamase (ESBL) producing Klebsiella infections are resistant to many beta-lactam antibiotics, including penicillins, cephalosporins, and monobactams.
  • Carbapenems are the drugs of choice for the treatment of ESBL-producing Klebsiella infections.
  • Carbapenems such as imipenem, meropenem, and ertapenem are broad-spectrum antibiotics that are effective against a wide range of Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria, including ESBL-producing Klebsiella.
  • Aztreonam, a monobactam antibiotic, Spectinomycin and streptomycin are not effective against ESBL-producing Klebsiella infections.

questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lippes’s loop

 

  • The non-medicated or inert IUDs are often referred to as first generation IUDs e.g.: Lippes loop the copper IUDs comprise the second and the hormone-releasing IUDs the third generation IUDs.

choices.text: Folic acid 5 mg to be started pre-conceptionally and continued throughout pregnancy
Single anti-epileptic drug at the least dose is preferred during pregnancy
Sodium valproate is safe and can be continued safely
There is an increased risk of developing childhood epilepsy in the fetus

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida with a known history of epilepsy on sodium valproate presents to the antenatal OPD at 6 weeks. All are advised except
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sodium valproate is safe and can be continued safely

 

  • Sodium valproate is safe and can be continued safely.
  • This is incorrect as sodium valproate is the most teratogenic of all anti-epileptic drugs.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Folic acid 5 mg to be started pre-conceptionally and continued throughout pregnancy. This is true as women on anti-epileptic drugs are at increased risk of developing neural tube defects. Folic acid reduces this risk.

 

  • Option B) Single anti-epileptic drug at the least dose is preferred during pregnancy. This would reduce the risk of fetal anomalies.
  • Option D) There is an increased risk of developing childhood epilepsy in the fetus. This statement is also correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pregnancy and epilepsy:
    • Generally low risk to the fetus.
    • There is an increased risk of major congenital malformations due to AEDs. However, certain AEDS like lamotrigine, levetiracetam and carbamazepine are commonly used and considered the safest agents. Poly-therapy increases the risk of malformations.
    • Sodium valproate infers the highest risk of congenital malformations (especially Neural tube defects).
    • Increased risk of Fetal growth restriction in women on AEDs.
    • There is an increased risk of developing childhood epilepsy in the fetus.
    • Folic acid (5mg) should be taken pre conceptionally and throughout pregnancy to reduce the risk of congenital malformations and long-term cognitive effects.
    • Aim for monotherapy with the longest effective AED dose if possible. If taking sodium valproate, this needs to be changed to an alternative AED.

 

Ref: William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Serum prothrombin time collectively measures all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Factor IX

 

  • Because of their rapid turnover, measurement of the clotting factors is the single best acute measure of hepatic synthetic function and helpful in both diagnosis and assessing the prognosis of acute parenchymal liver disease.
  • Useful for this purpose is the serum prothrombin time, which collectively measures factors II, V, VII, and X.
  • Biosynthesis of factors II, VII, IX, and X depends on vitamin K.

 

Ref: Harrison’s 21st edition, page no. 2555

choices.text: Contraindicated in persons with hyperlipidemia
It can cause increased sensitivity to sunlight
Female patients should avoid getting pregnant for 3 years after therapy
Acitretin has a half-life of about 50 hours

questions.text: A dermatologist wants to prescribe acitretin to a patient with psoriasis. Which of the following statements is false regarding the drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contraindicated in persons with hyperlipidemia.

 

  • The false statement regarding acitretin is that it is contraindicated in persons with hyperlipidemia.
  • In fact, acitretin is known to improve lipid profiles by reducing triglycerides and increasing HDL cholesterol levels.
  • It is a retinoid that is used to treat severe psoriasis and other dermatological disorders.
  • The other statements are true regarding acitretin.
  • Acitretin can cause increased sensitivity to sunlight, and patients should be advised to use sun protection and avoid excessive sun exposure during therapy.
  • Female patients of childbearing age should avoid getting pregnant after therapy because acitretin is teratogenic and can cause fetal malformations.
  • Effective contraception should be used during treatment and for at least 3 years after therapy.
  • Acitretin has a half-life of about 50 hours, which means it can take several weeks for the drug to be eliminated from the body after discontinuing therapy. This long half-life also means that accumulation of the drug can occur with repeated dosing, increasing the risk of toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following indicator is used to measure the development of the diseases when different individuals were followed up for different period of time (due to death/ migration of individual because of different cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Incidence rate

 

  • When different individuals are observed for different lengths of time, incidence rate (also called an incidence density) is calculated, in which the denominator consists of the sum of the units of time that each individual was at risk and was observed.
  • The measure of incidence can be interpreted as the average probability, or risk, that an individual will develop a disease during a specified period of time.

 

 

Ref: Leon Gordis, 5th edition, page no. 49

choices.text: It is a branch of mandibular nerve
It is responsible for saliva secretion from parotid gland
It receives taste sensation from all the 3 papillae present in tongue
It courses through the tympanic membrane

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl returned home after college. She sat down to sip down the coffee prepared by her mother. As soon as she took sipped her first sip, she felt a burning sensation over the tip of the dorsum of the tongue. Which of the following statement is true about the nerve responsible for this burning sensation experienced by this girl?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a branch of mandibular nerve

 

  • The nerve responsible for carrying general sensation from anterior 2/3 of the tongue is lingual nerve which is branch of mandibular nerve.
  • Anatomical Origin: The lingual nerve is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (Cranial Nerve V3).
  • Sensory Function: It is primarily responsible for providing general sensory innervation (such as touch, pain, and temperature) to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • Taste Function: It also carries taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, but these fibers are actually part of the chorda tympani nerve (a branch of the facial nerve or CN VII), which joins the lingual nerve in its course.
  • Course: The nerve descends between the medial pterygoid muscle and the mandible, then passes beneath the mucous membrane on the inner side of the mandible, and finally approaches the tongue.
  • Relation to Oral Structures: In its course, the lingual nerve runs close to the lower third molars, which makes it susceptible to injury during dental procedures.
  • Clinical Significance: Damage to the lingual nerve can result in numbness, loss of taste, or altered sensation in the tongue, which can affect speech and eating.
  • Association with Other Nerves: It is often closely associated with the submandibular ganglion and various branches of the facial nerve.
  • Variation: There can be variations in the course and branching pattern of the lingual nerve, important to note during surgical procedures in the oral cavity.
  • Regeneration: Like other peripheral nerves, the lingual nerve has some capacity for regeneration, but recovery from injury can be incomplete or may result in neuropathic pain or dysaesthesia.
  • Understanding the lingual nerve's anatomy, course, and clinical significance is crucial for dental and medical professionals, especially those involved in surgeries or procedures in the oral and maxillofacial region.
  • The nerve responsible for carrying sensation from anterior 2/3 of the tongue is chorda tympani
    • It arises from the facial nerve about 6mm above stylomastoid foramen and then passes through the tympanic membrane between it mucus and fibrous layers.
    • Chorda tympani carries preganglionic secretomotor fibres for submandibular and sublingual salivary gland.
    • Taste buds of circumvallate papillae innervated by glossopharyngeal nerve taste buds of fungiform papillae alone innervated by chorda tympani nerve filiform papillae has no taste buds.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy, 41st edition, page no. 502
