questions.text: All-trans-retinoic acid [ATRA] is useful in treatment of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute promyelocytic leukemia

 

  • However, the prognosis of APL patients has changed dramatically with the introduction of tretinoin (all-trans-retinoic acid [ATRA]), an oral drug that induces the differentiation of leukemic cells bearing the t(15;17), where disruption of the RARA gene encoding a retinoid acid receptor occurs. ATRA decreases the frequency of DIC but often produces another complication called the APL (differentiation) syndrome.

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student, who had a history of frequent respiratory infections as a child, presents to the OPD. He has been experiencing recurrent episodes of coughing and shortness of breath over the past few months. He also complains of fatigue and chest pain, particularly on the left side. The CT scan reveals a mass in the lower lobe of his left lung as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sequestration

 

  • Pulmonary sequestration is a rare congenital abnormality where lung tissue develops abnormally with no communication with the rest of the tracheobronchial tree. This tissue gets its blood supply from aorta.
  • The most common site of sequestered lung segment is the left lower lobe.
  • Hallmark: Feeding vessel from aorta
  • IOC: CT angiography

choices.text: Disorder of sleep arousal.
Person will have full consciousness.
Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion.
There may be neurological conditions associated.

questions.text: What is the false statement regarding somnambulism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Person will have full consciousness.

 

  • Somnambulism, also known as sleepwalking, is a disorder of arousal from slow-wave sleep.
  • Individuals who are sleepwalking typically act without conscious awareness and usually have no memory of the episode upon awakening.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Disorder of sleep arousal. True. Sleepwalking arises from deep, non-REM (NREM) stage 4 sleep, making it a disorder of arousal.

 

Option C) Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion. True. When sleepwalkers are awakened, they are often disoriented and confused.

 

Option D) There may be neurological conditions associated. True. While many cases of somnambulism have no clear cause, certain neurological conditions can be associated with it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sleepwalking (somnambulism) is an arousal disorder originating from deep, non-REM stage 4 sleep.
  • Individuals who sleepwalk typically act without conscious awareness and have no memory of the episode upon awakening.
  • The person who is having sleep walking is difficult to awake.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No. 555

choices.text: Vitamin D intoxication
Metastatic carcinoma of bone

questions.text: A 75-year-old man had complaints of weakness, polyuria, intense thirst, difficulty in speaking, hypertension, confusion, and weight loss of more than 7 kgs. He was on treatment for osteoarthritis, and took 1,00,000 units of Vitamin D every day for 3 months. His plasma calcium was 15.5 mg/dL. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin D intoxication

 

  • Therapeutic doses varying from 2000-4000 IU/day or weekly doses are given.
  • Doses above 10,000U/day for long periods may cause toxicity.
  • Symptoms: weakness, polyuria, intense thirst, difficulty in speaking, hypertension, and weight loss.
  • Hypercalcemia leads to calcification of soft tissues (calcinosis).
  • Although vitamins are toxic in higher doses, excessive exposure to sunlight does not result in vitamin toxicity, because excess D3 is destroyed by sunlight itself.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Hypercalcemia. Here, the blood calcium level is >> 11 mg/dL and there is osteoporosis with X-ray pictures of punched out areas of bone resorption. High calcium and alkaline phosphatase levels and low phosphate levels in blood.

 

Option C) Paget’s disease. It is characterized by osteoclastic bone resorption and disordered replacement of bone, common above 40 years which might affect one or several bones.

 

Option D) Metastatic carcinoma of bone. Drastically high levels of ALP is seen with bone resorption and hypercalcemia.

 

Ref: Vasudevan, 9th edition, page no. 473

choices.text: Inhibits the release of acetylcholine
Release of noradrenaline at synaptic cleft
Selectively and irreversibly inhibits nicotinic receptors
Stimulates muscarinic and nicotinic receptors

questions.text: An elderly woman received a Botox injection for the treatment of wrinkles.  Which of the following is the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibits the release of acetylcholine

 

  • The botulinum toxin works by preventing acetylcholine from entering the synaptic cleft.
  • Acetylcholine is exocytosed by SNARE protein, which is broken down by botulinum toxin.
  • Consequently, it prevents acetylcholine from being released.
  • Other agents that regulate the level of Ach in the synapse are:
    • Hemicholinium acts by inhibiting choline uptake (the rate limiting step in the synthesis of acetylcholine)
    • Vesamicol inhibits the uptake of Acetylcholine into the vesicles.
    • Physostigmine inhibits the breakdown of Ach at the synaptic cleft by the action of Acetylcholine esterase.

questions.text: Match the items of column A with column B
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-e, 2-d, 3-c, 4-a, 5-b, 6-f

 

  • The correct match is given in below table.

 

  1.  

 

  1. Loss of frontal-parietal hairline: e) Androgenic alopecia
    • Androgenic alopecia commonly manifests as a receding hairline at the temples and can progress to affect the frontal-parietal region.
  2. Chemotherapy-induced hair loss: d) Anagen effluvium
    • Anagen effluvium typically occurs due to chemotherapy which affects rapidly dividing hair follicle cells, leading to widespread hair loss.
  3. Hairs of varying lengths in alopecia patch: c) Trichotillomania
    • Trichotillomania, a hair-pulling disorder, results in patches of hair loss with broken hairs of various lengths.
  4. Peribulbar inflammation: a) Alopecia areata
    • Alopecia areata is characterized by immune-mediated peribulbar inflammation described as swarm of bees appearance around hair follicles, leading to patchy hair loss.
  5. Stress-induced hair loss: b) Telogen effluvium
    • Telogen effluvium is often triggered by stress, causing diffuse hair shedding when hairs enter the telogen (resting) phase prematurely.
  6. Scarring alopecia: f) Lichen planopilaris
    • Lichen planopilaris is a type of scarring alopecia that results in permanent hair loss due to inflammation that destroys the hair follicle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Identify common types of alopecia and their associated clinical features to aid in diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy came to consult you in your OPD where he gave history of trauma to his right eye. On carrying out slit-lamp examination, you see a superficial injury on the cornea. Usually, in injuries involving only the corneal epithelium, the stratified squamous epithelium rapidly regenerates because of the presence of stem cells. Where are the Palisades of Vogt containing the stem cells located?

Ans. B) Limbus

questions.text: A 48-year-old patient with CML presented with fever for the past 10 days. He was referred from another hospital and was on a broad-spectrum antibiotic for the past 7 days. Despite this, the fever continued. The doctor requested for Beta-D-glucan assay, which will be helpful for diagnosis of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Invasive candidiasis

 

  • Beta-D-glucan assay helps in invasive candidiasis which is a non-invasive test done in serum samples.
  • Beta-D-Glucan assay is done for Candida, Aspergillus, Pneumocystis
  • It is negative in cases of Mucormycosis and Cryptococcus.

 

Other options:

 

Invasive aspergillosis is diagnosed by galactomannan assay.

 

Ref: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th edition, Page No. 320

choices.text: Primary health center

questions.text: Which entity is responsible for managing the school health programs?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primary health center

 

  • In India, the School Health Committee recommended that school health services be integrated with general health services, which are managed by primary health centers (PHCs).
  • To ensure effective implementation, the committee proposed the formation of school health committees at various levels.
  • PHCs are responsible for providing a range of school health services such as health assessments, vision and hearing tests, dental check-ups, treatment for common illnesses, immunization, micronutrient management, deworming, and provision of mid-day meals.

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the prostate forms the uvula vesicae?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Median

 

  • The uvula vesicae is formed by the prostate's median lobe.
  • The uvula vesicae is a slight elevation on the trigone immediately posterior to the urethral orifice caused by the median lobe of the prostate.
  • In benign prostatic hypertrophy, it is frequently enlarged.

 

 

  • Also called the middle lobe or median lobe, this portion of the prostate is situated between the ejaculatory ducts and the urethra. When the median lobe enlarges due to conditions like benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), it can project into the bladder, forming a structure called the "uvula vesicae."
  • It is also known as Lietaud’s uvula.
  • This growth can cause urinary symptoms by obstructing the bladder neck.

 

Let's discuss each lobe of the prostate in detail:

 

Option A) Anterior. The anterior lobe of the prostate, also referred to as the anterior fibromuscular stroma, is found at the front of the prostate, facing the pubic symphysis. Contrary to the other sections of the prostate, this area is primarily made up of fibromuscular tissue and contains fewer glandular elements. It doesn't commonly give rise to clinical conditions like benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) or prostate cancer.

 

Option B) Posterior. The posterior lobe is located at the back of the prostate, facing the rectum. This part of the prostate is significant clinically because it's the most common site for the development of prostate cancer. During a digital rectal exam, the physician can palpate this lobe, and any firm or irregular nodules felt here could suggest malignancy.

 

Option D) Lateral. The lateral lobes are the large bilateral portions of the prostate on either side of the urethra. These are the most voluminous parts of the prostate and are typically the primary sites involved in benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), a common condition in older men where the prostate enlarges and can cause urinary obstruction.

choices.text: Longitudinal pancreatico-jejunostomy or Peusthow’s procedure

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented with features of chronic pancreatitis with recurrent attacks and has a 10 mm dilatation of the pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi present with calcifications in the head region. Which of these procedures is likely to be offered to the patient for relief of pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Frey’s procedure

 

  • Inflammation or calcifications in head of pancreas with dilated duct requires combined head coring + Longitudinal PJ.
  • Combined procedure: if problem in head (inflammation) + duct strictures → Frey’s procedure: head coring + longitudinal pancreatico-jejunostomy
  • Drainage procedures: duct dilated with stones → cut it open → pancreatic duct to jejunal anastomosis along the length → longitudinal pancreatico-jejunostomy/Puestow’s procedure
  • Resectional procedures: distal pancreatectomy.
  • Duodenal preserving pancreatic head resection aka Beger’s procedure.

questions.text: Which of the following generally occurs first among the major developmental events of female puberty?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thelarche

 

  • In most girls, breast budding, termed thelarche, is the first physical sign of puberty and begins at approximately age 10 years.
  • In a minority, pubic hair growth, known as pubarche, develops first.
  • Following breast and pubic hair growth, adolescents undergo an accelerated increase in height, termed a growth spurt, during a 3-year span rom ages 10.5 to 13.5 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In most girls, breast budding, termed thelarche, is the first physical sign of puberty and begins at approximately age 10 years.
  • In a minority, pubic hair growth, known as pubarche, develops first.
  • Following breast and pubic hair growth, adolescents undergo an accelerated increase in height, termed a growth spurt, during a 3-year span rom ages 10.5 to 13.5 years.

 

Ref: Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition, Page no. 347

questions.text: A mother with a history of seizure episodes brings her 2 days old newborn to the pediatric department. She admits that she was taking valproate during her entire course of pregnancy and as her gynecologist advised that her child may have neural tube defects, so to confirm she reached out to you. You will plan to do radiological investigations in all of the situations of the child except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Coccygeal pits

 

  • In case of Coccygeal pits, imaging for the suspicion of spina bifida occulta is not indicated.

 

IMAGING INDICATED

 

  • Subcutaneous mass or lipoma
  • Hairy patch
  • Dermal sinus
  • Atypical dimples (deep, >5 mm, >25 mm from anal verge)
  • Vascular lesion, e.g., hemangioma or telangiectasia
  • Skin appendages or polypoid lesions, e.g., skin tags, tail-like appendages
  • Scar-like lesions

 

IMAGING UNCERTAIN

 

  • Hyperpigmented patches
  • Deviation of the gluteal fold  

 

IMAGING NOT REQUIRED

 

  • Simple dimples (<5 mm, <25 mm from anal verge)
  • Coccygeal pits

 

Other options:

 

Option A, B and D are the indications for radiological investigations in suspicion of spina bifida occulta.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No. 2805-2806

questions.text: In which of the following reflexes, gastric emptying is delayed when acidic content enters the duodenum?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Enterogastric

 

  • Enterogastric reflex is the reflex that inhibits gastric emptying.
  • It is elicited by the presence of chyme in the duodenum, which prevents further emptying of stomach.
  • Mechanism of enterogastric reflex:
    1. Presence of chyme in duodenum causes generation of nerve impulses which are transmitted to stomach by the intrinsic nerve fibers of GI tract. After reaching the stomach, these impulses inhibit emptying.
    2. Impulses from duodenum pass via extrinsic sympathetic fibers to stomach and inhibit emptying.
    3. Some impulses from duodenum travel through afferent vagal fibers to the brainstem. Normally, brainstem neurons send excitatory impulses to stomach through efferent vagal fibers and stimulate gastric emptying. However, the impulses from duodenum inhibit these brainstem neurons and thereby inhibit gastric emptying.
  • Factors which initiate enterogastric reflex:
    1. Duodenal distension
    2. Irritation of the duodenal mucosa
    3. Acidity of the chyme
    4. Osmolality of the chime
    5. Breakdown products of proteins and fats

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with tachypnea and mental confusion. His blood sugar is 350 mg/dL, pH – 7.2, HCO3- - 10 mEq/L, pCO2 – 25 mmHg. What is the metabolic abnormality?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metabolic Acidosis

 

Steps:

 

  • pH is on acidic side.
  • HCO3- in on acidic side (< 24 mEq/L), while pCO2 is on basic side (< 35 mmHg).
  • Therefore, Metabolic acidosis is the main metabolic abnormality which was compensated by respiratory system via decreasing pCO2 values.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with rigidity and tremors. On examination, he has blank facial expressions. Which of the following drugs can be used to manage this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Selegiline

 

  • The patient's symptoms of rigidity, tremors, and blank facial expressions are suggestive of Parkinson's disease, a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra.
  • Selegiline is a monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) inhibitor that is used in the management of Parkinson's disease.
  • It works by inhibiting the breakdown of dopamine, thereby increasing its availability in the brain and helping to alleviate symptoms like rigidity and tremors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Clozapine. Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic primarily used in the treatment of schizophrenia. While it can be used in Parkinson's disease patients who experience psychosis, it is not a first-line treatment for the primary motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease.

 

Option B) Donepezil. Donepezil is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used in the treatment of Alzheimer’s disease. It enhances cholinergic function by increasing the concentration of acetylcholine in the brain. It is not typically used for treating Parkinson's disease.

 

Option D) Haloperidol. Haloperidol is a typical antipsychotic and can actually worsen Parkinson's disease symptoms. It blocks dopamine receptors, which could exacerbate the dopamine deficiency characteristic of Parkinson's disease.

choices.text: Peutz Jegher syndrome

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was admitted to the hospital with a history of prolapsing rectal mass and painless rectal bleeding. The histopathological image of the mass is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Juvenile Polyp

 

  • The clinical features and the histopathological image showing characteristic cystically dilated crypts and glands are suggestive of a juvenile polyp.
  • Juvenile (retention) polyps are mucosal epithelial and lamina propria malformations.
  • These can be sporadic or syndromic, but their morphology is often indistinguishable.
  • The vast majority of juvenile polyps are found in children under the age of five.
  • When found in adults, polyps with the same morphology are sometimes referred to as inflammatory polyps.
  • The majority of juvenile polyps are in the rectum and cause painless rectal bleeding.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Puetz Jegher syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant syndrome that manifests as multiple GI hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation at the age of 11 years.

 

 

 

Option B) and Option D) Adenomas are intraepithelial neoplasms that range in size from small polyps to large sessile lesions. There is no preference for either gender, and both are present in nearly 50% of adults living in the Western world by age 50. Adenomas can be classified as tubular, tubulovillous, or villous based on their architecture.

choices.text: Hot air oven

questions.text: Which of the sterilization methods should be appropriate for this culture?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inspissation

 

  • Inspissation is a sterilization method that is used for culture media that has egg or serum.
  • The above image shows LJ media which is used for the growth of M.tuberculosis.
  • The Temperature used is 80-85C and the method is repeated for three successive days.

 

 

Ref: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 12th edition, Page No. 126

choices.text: Female Anopheles mosquito

questions.text: A bubonic outbreak has occurred within the community. What is the responsible vector for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Xenopsylla cheopis

 

  • Xenopsylla cheopis, commonly known as a rat flea, serves as the carrier for the bubonic plague.
  • This particular flea species can be recognized by its distinctive conical-shaped head, along with a thorax, abdomen, and three sets of legs.

 

 

 

  • Plague is a zoonotic disease caused by Yersinia pestis.
  • The reservoir of infections is wild rodents.
  • Humans acquire the disease by the bite of an infected flea, by direct contact with the tissues of the infected animal, or by droplet infection from cases of pneumonic plague.
  • Human plague mainly presents as:
    • Bubonic plague: This is the most common type of disease. There is fever along with painful lymphadenitis. Within a few days, the lymph nodes in the groin, axilla, or neck enlarge and are called buboes. This is followed by the suppuration of the buboes.
    • Pneumonic plague: It develops as a complication of bubonic-septicemic plague.
    • Septicemic plague: It occurs when the infection spreads to blood.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Species Phlebotomus argentipes, belongs to the group of sand fly. It transmits kala azar. Other diseases transmitted by sand flies are sandfly fever and oriental sore.

 

Option C) Ixodes Tick transmits Lyme’s disease caused by Borrelia burgdorferi.

 

Option D) Female Anopheles mosquito transmits malaria.

questions.text: A 7-year-old female child has involuntary movements in right hand which has been worsening over the past month. She also has difficulty in vision for the past 1 year. Blood investigations reveals elevated serum homocysteine levels with normal LFT, RFT, TFT and serum electrolytes. The patient was prescribed a high dose of pyridoxine- and methionine-restricted diet. The follow-up after 3 months shows improvement in dystonic movements. What may be the disorder that this child may be suffering from?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Classical Homocystinuria

 

  • Classical homocystinuria is due to the deficiency of the enzyme, cystathionine beta Synthase.
  • Clinical features:
    • Failure to thrive, developmental delay, ectopia lentis, severe myopia, cataracts, retinal detachment, and optic atrophy.
    • Progressive mental retardation, skeletal abnormalities may resemble Marfan syndrome.
    • Thromboembolic episodes may be seen at any age.
    • Elevated homocysteine level is a risk factor for CAD, CVA, PAD and DVT.
    • During pregnancy, it causes neural tube defects and pre-eclampsia.
  • Diagnosis: amino acid screen in urine and blood (homocysteine and methionine are elevated, cystine will be low), liver biopsy, enzyme assay, skeletal X-ray, skin fibroblast enzyme assay, standard ophthalmic testing, and genetic testing.
  • Treatment with high doses of pyridoxine, folic acid, B12 and betaine reduces homocysteine levels.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Hartnup’s disease. Due to defective absorption of aromatic amino acids from intestine as well as reabsorption from renal tubules → excretion of amino acids in urine.

 

Option B) Cystinuria. Due to defect/deficiency of transporter system → patients cannot reabsorb cysteine into their bloodstream → accumulation of cystine in urine forms stones → leads to recurrent nephrolithiasis, obstruction, and finally renal failure.

 

Option D) Cystathioninuria. Due to cystathionase deficiency, patient presents with mental retardation, anemia, thrombocytopenia and endocrinopathies.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan, 9th edition, page no. 221

choices.text: Peptic ulcer bleed
Esophageal variceal bleed

questions.text: A patient presents in emergency department with sudden hematemesis. He has been taking aspirin for his arthritis and drinks alcohol occasionally. He gives a history of occasional abdominal pain. On examination, there is no abdominal mass, distension or tenderness. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peptic ulcer

 

  • This patient most likely has a bleeding peptic ulcer.
  • NSAIDs like aspirin interferes with the protective role of Prostaglandins on gastric and duodenal mucosa from acid and pepsin, and increase the risk of peptic ulcer formation in the stomach and the duodenum.
  • They present with Pain in epigastrium, bleeding, vomiting.
  • Sequelae:
    • Bleed (Duodenal > Gastric ulcer) – MC complication of peptic ulcer
    • Perforation → peritonitis (duodenal > gastric)
    • Stricture → gastric outlet obstruction
    • Malignancy → only in gastric ulcers

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Mallory-Weiss tears occur following repeated vomiting/retching – alcoholic binge. Self-limiting, no profuse hematemesis

 

Option B) Boerhaave syndrome is esophageal perforation which presents with chest pain, vomiting and subcutaneous emphysema (not hematemesis).

 

Option D) Esophageal variceal bleed commonly occur in portal hypertension patients with cirrhosis. There is no splenomegaly or ascites seen in the given patient, which is a typical finding in portal hypertension.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient with a history of rheumatoid arthritis has been experiencing visual changes, including blurry vision and halos around lights. She has been on medication for her rheumatoid arthritis for a couple of years now. Which of the following drugs she might be taking is known to get deposited in the cornea?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chloroquine

 

  • Chloroquine, an antimalarial drug also used in rheumatoid arthritis, can get deposited in various ocular tissues, including the cornea and retina.
  • Corneal deposits are usually reversible upon discontinuation of the drug but can lead to visual disturbances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Leflunomide. Leflunomide is an immunomodulatory drug used in rheumatoid arthritis but is not known for deposition in the cornea. It has a different side effect profile mainly affecting the liver and gastrointestinal system.

 

Option C) Methotrexate. Methotrexate is a commonly used drug for rheumatoid arthritis but does not get deposited in the cornea. It has its own set of side effects like bone marrow suppression, liver toxicity, and gastrointestinal disturbances.

 

Option D) Sulfasalazine. Sulfasalazine is also used for rheumatoid arthritis but is not known to deposit in the cornea. Its main side effects include gastrointestinal symptoms, skin rash, and rarely, hematologic abnormalities.

choices.text: Subluxation of lens
Mitral valve prolapse
Bilateral small streak ovaries

questions.text: The mother of a 12-year-old girl was worried that her daughter is shorter when compared with her classmates. On examination, the child had a webbed neck, low hairline, and shield chest. A provisional diagnosis of Turner's syndrome was made. Which of the following is a likely finding to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bilateral small streak ovaries

 

  • The likely finding seen in a patient with Turner syndrome is bilateral small streak ovaries.
  • Turner syndrome results from complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome. It is characterized by hypogonadism in phenotypic females. It is the most common sex chromosome abnormality in females. Three types of karyotypic abnormalities are seen:
    • Missing an entire X chromosome: This results in a 45X0 karyotype.
    • Structural abnormalities of the X chromosomes
    • Mosaics: They will have 45X along with one or more karyotypically normal or abnormal cell types. Examples are 45X/46XX, 45X/46XY, 45X/47XXX, 45×/46X, ¡(X)(q10).
  • Important features associated with Turner's syndrome:

 

 

  • Short stature
  • Webbing of neck
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Cubitus valgus
  • Streak ovaries
  • Infertility, amenorrhea
  • Peripheral lymphedema at birth
  • Low posterior hairline
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Pigmented nevi
  • Coarctation of aorta
  • Normal secondary sex characteristics do not develop during puberty.
  • The genitalia remain infantile, breast development is inadequate, and pubic hair is scarce.
  • In adults, short stature and amenorrhea are especially important in establishing the diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient was suspected to have acute brucellosis. A serum sample was sent for a standard agglutination test. It came out to be negative initially but after serial dilutions of the serum sample, the test turned out to be positive. Which of the following is responsible for the initial negative test?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prozone phenomenon

 

  • The initial negative test is explained by the prozone phenomenon.
  • The standard agglutination test is a tube agglutination test that mainly identifies IgM antibodies.
  • It is used in establishing a diagnosis of acute brucellosis.
  • Prozone phenomenon refers to the failure of a visible precipitation reaction due to inhibition of lattice formation by the presence of excessive antibodies. This gives rise to a false-negative test.
  • This excess in antibodies can be overcome by diluting the serum sample, leading to an increase in the antigen-antibody interactions, eventually giving rise to a positive result.
  • Lattice hypothesis:
    • The lattice hypothesis explains precipitation reactions.
    • The amount of precipitate formed is greatly influenced by the relative proportions of antigens and antibodies.
  • Prozone phenomenon: Caused by excessive antibodies in the test system. (weak/absent precipitation-false-negative test)
  • Zone of equivalence: Antigens and antibodies are in optimum proportions and maximum precipitation occurs.
  • Post-zone phenomenon: (Option D) Due to the presence of excessive antigen in the test system. (weaker/absent precipitation)

questions.text: A man is caught peeping into the bathroom of a girl’s hostel and trying to watch the female inhabitants bathe. This sexual perversion is defined as:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Voyeurism

 

  • Voyeurism: Recurrent urge or behaviour to observe an unsuspecting person who is naked, disrobing or engaging in sexual activities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Frotteurism. Sexual gratification by rubbing private part.

 

Option B) Masochism. Recurrent urge or behaviour of wanting to be humiliated, beaten, bound, or otherwise made to suffer.

 

Option C) Exhibitionism. Recurrent urge or behaviour to expose one's genitals to an unsuspecting person.

 

OTHER SEXUAL PERVERSIONS

 

  • Urolagnia: Sexual pleasure is obtained by witnessing the act of urination.
  • Transvestism: Sexual gratification by wearing clothes of opposite sex.
  • Fetishism: Use of non-sexual or non-living objects or part of a person's body to gain sexual excitement. Partialism refers to fetishes specifically involving nonsexual parts of the body.
  • Paedophilia: Sexual attraction to children.
  • Sadism: Recurrent urge or behaviour involving acts in which the pain or humiliation of the victim is sexually exciting.

 

Ref: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no. 430

choices.text: Radial head fracture
Lateral condyle fracture of the humerus
Medial epicondyle avulsion fracture
Supracondylar humerus fracture

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the orthopedic clinic with a cubitus varus deformity of the right elbow. He has a history of trauma to his elbow three months ago. Upon clinical examination, the patient's elbow shows the preserved 3 bony point relationship. What is the most probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supracondylar humerus fracture

 

  • Supracondylar humerus fracture is the most likely diagnosis given the history of trauma.
  • Supracondylar fractures often require prompt recognition and appropriate management to prevent long-term deformities.
  • This fracture, common in pediatric populations, can result in cubitus varus deformity due to malunion.
  • The preserved 3 bony point relationship on examination suggests adequate reduction, but the deformity persists.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Radial head fracture. Radial head fractures typically involve the proximal part of the radius and are not directly associated with cubitus varus deformity. They may present with localized pain and limited range of motion in the elbow.

 

Option B) Lateral condyle fracture of the humerus. Lateral condyle fractures are more likely to result in a cubitus valgus deformity rather than cubitus varus. These fractures involve the lateral aspect of the distal humerus and affect the growth plate, leading to deformities.

 

Option C) Medial epicondyle avulsion fracture. Medial epicondyle avulsion fractures are common in pediatric elbow injuries but are not associated with cubitus varus. They typically result from forceful valgus stress during activities like throwing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The educational objective for this case is to understand the importance of recognizing a cubitus varus deformity in a pediatric patient with a history of trauma.
  • In this context, a malunited supracondylar fracture of the humerus is the most probable cause, and early identification and appropriate management are essential to prevent long-term functional impairment.
  • Cubitus varus deformity is characterized by the abnormal angulation of the elbow, which can affect range of motion and daily activities if left untreated.

choices.text: Cervical Vertebral Osteomyelitis
Malignancy with Metastasis to Cervical Vertebrae
Chronic Prevertebral Abscess Secondary to Tuberculosis

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with chronic neck pain, low-grade fever, and unexplained weight loss over the past few months. On examination, there is a palpable mass in the anterior neck region, which is firm and non-movable. Radiographic imaging shows destruction of the cervical vertebral bodies with a prevertebral soft tissue mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic Prevertebral Abscess Secondary to Tuberculosis

 

  • Tuberculosis can cause Pott's disease, which is tuberculosis of the spine, leading to vertebral destruction and the formation of a cold abscess, which can present as a prevertebral mass in the neck.
  • Chronic prevertebral abscess is tubercular in nature and is the result of:
    1. Caries of cervical spine or
    2. Tuberculosis infection of retropharyngeal lymph nodes secondary to tuberculosis of deep cervical nodes
  • The clinical presentation is suggestive of a chronic infection with systemic signs, and the radiographic findings indicate a process involving the vertebral bodies and prevertebral area.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Cervical Vertebral Osteomyelitis. While osteomyelitis could present with vertebral destruction and abscess formation, the chronicity of symptoms and systemic signs like weight loss are more suggestive of tuberculosis, especially in the appropriate epidemiological context.

 

Option B) Malignancy with Metastasis to Cervical Vertebrae. Malignancy could cause vertebral destruction and a palpable neck mass, but it would not typically present as an abscess. The chronic nature of the symptoms and systemic signs like weight loss raise the suspicion for a chronic infection like tuberculosis rather than a primary malignancy.

 

Option D) Thyroid carcinoma can present as a neck mass and might involve cervical structures, but it would not typically cause destruction of the cervical vertebral bodies or present as a soft tissue mass consistent with an abscess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize the presentation of chronic prevertebral abscess secondary to tuberculosis, which includes systemic symptoms such as weight loss, chronic neck pain, and radiographic evidence of vertebral destruction and soft tissue mass.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, page no. 267

choices.text: Unpaired T test
Paired T test

questions.text: The preferred test for evaluating the difference in means between two study groups, where one group functions as a control, is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Unpaired T test

 

  • The test of choice to measure the difference in means between two groups in a study, with one group being a control is unpaired T test.

questions.text: A team of emergency responders has been called to the scene of a bomb blast in a crowded city center. Upon arrival, they find multiple casualties with various injuries, including blast injuries. In a blast injury, which of the following organs is least vulnerable to the blast wave?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Liver

 

  • The liver, being a solid and dense organ, is least vulnerable to the direct effects of a blast wave.
  • However, this does not mean it's immune to blast injuries altogether.
  • Secondary or tertiary mechanisms, like being struck by flying debris or crushed against another object, can still cause liver injuries.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) GI tract. The gastrointestinal (GI) tract, particularly the hollow parts like the stomach and intestines, is susceptible to blast injuries due to the presence of air within these structures. Typical injuries include subserosal hemorrhage, cecal and ileal perforation.

 

Option B) Lungs. The lungs are among the most vulnerable organs to a blast injury. Being air-filled and highly delicate, they can sustain significant injury from the sudden pressure wave generated by an explosion. Pulmonary barotrauma can lead to potentially life-threatening conditions like pneumothorax (collapsed lung), hemothorax (blood in the pleural cavity), and pulmonary contusion (bruising of the lung tissue).

 

Option D) Tympanic membrane. The tympanic membrane is particularly sensitive to sudden pressure changes and the most commonly injured organ. It can easily rupture from the pressure wave of a blast, making it a common injury in explosion scenarios. A ruptured eardrum can cause hearing loss and pain.

 

  • In summary, while all the organs listed can be injured during an explosion, the liver, being a solid organ, is least vulnerable to the primary blast wave compared to the air-filled structures like the lungs and GI tract or the delicate eardrum.

choices.text: Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section
Acyclovir and induction of labor
Antiviral and normal vaginal delivery

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida presents at 36 weeks with painful vulval ulcers. She does not give history of similar lesions ever in the past. On examination, there are multiple painful vesicular lesions. Which is the best treatment option?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section

 

  • The diagnosis in this woman is genital herpes simplex (HSV).
  • Since she has never had similar lesions in the past, this is primary genital herpes.
  • The risk of neonatal infection following vaginal delivery with primary HSV is very high (up to 50%). Neonatal herpes has a very high mortality rate.
  • Antivirals (Acyclovir) have to be started.
  • Hence, the recommended mode of delivery in primary HSV is elective cesarean section.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Primary genital HSV infection is a contra-indication to vaginal delivery and a cesarean section should be done.

 

Ref: High Risk Pregnancy: Management Options; David James, Philip J Steer; 5th edition, Page no. 673

choices.text: Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (paO2)
Increase in systemic vascular resistance
Increase in circulating prostaglandin levels
Decrease in pulmonary venous resistance

questions.text: Which of the following is the main factor for the ductal closure postnatally?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (paO2)

 

  • Oxygen is the most important factor controlling ductal closure.
  • Oxygen is a good smooth muscle constrictor.
  • Once the baby cries, oxygen enters the lungs during inspiration and that causes closure of the ductus arteriosus.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) In fetal circulation, there is decrease in systemic vascular resistance.

 

Option C) Placenta secretes prostaglandin PGE2 which keeps the ductus arteriosus OPEN.

 

Option D) In fetal circulation, there is a decrease in pulmonary vascular resistance but that is not responsible for closure of ductus arteriosus.

choices.text: Normal pressure hydrocephalus

questions.text: An elderly woman is brought to the OPD with complaints of behavioral change, a history of multiple falls, urinary incontinence, and dementia. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Normal pressure hydrocephalus

 

  • NPH is characterized by Dementia, Apraxia/Magnetic gait with urinary incontinence due to frontal lobe dysfunction.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Frontotemporal dementia. Characterized by early personality changes. Falls are not common.

 

Option C) Parkinson disease. Idiopathic PD does not present with upfront dementia. Presence of dementia within 1 year of onset of motor symptoms suggest Lewy body dementia.

 

Option D) CJD is associated with myoclonus, rapid progressive dementia.

 

Ref: Harrison, Dementia, Chapter 434

choices.text: Capsular tension rings (CTR)

questions.text: A cataract surgeon noticed zonular dehiscence in a patient preoperatively of less than 2 o' clock hours. What precaution can be taken during surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Capsular tension rings (CTR)

 

  • The presence of zonular weakness increases the risk of intra- and postoperative complications from cataract surgery, including posterior capsular rupture, vitreous loss, and lens dislocation and decentration.

 

 

 

  • Capsular support devices facilitate safe and successful cataract surgery by improving capsular bag stability and centration.
  • These devices consist of:
    1. capsular tension rings (A),
    2. modified capsular tension rings (B),
    3. capsular tension segments (C), and
    4. capsular retention hooks (D). 

 

 

Ref: https://eyewiki.aao.org/Capsular_Support_Devices

questions.text: A patient presented with clinical features of ataxia and incoordination. This is due to thrombosis of which artery?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Superior cerebellar

  • Thrombosis of the superior cerebellar artery causes cerebellar lesion which presents with ataxia and incoordination.
  • The superior cerebellar artery (SCA) is a branch of the basilar artery and supplies the superior surface of the cerebellum, the roof nuclei, and parts of the midbrain.
  • When there is a thrombosis (formation of a blood clot) in the SCA, the blood supply to these areas is disrupted, which can cause various neurological symptoms such as ataxia, incoordination, and dizziness.
  • Blood supply of cerebellum:
    • Superior cerebellar artery
    • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
    • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Common symptoms of cerebellar lesions:

 

 

Let's delve into the effects of thrombosis (blockage) in each of the mentioned arteries:

 

Option A) Posterior cerebral artery (PCA).

 

  • It supplies blood to the occipital lobe, parts of the temporal lobe, and the inferomedial portion of the thalamus.
  • Thrombosis of the PCA can lead to:
    • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia (loss of half of the field of vision in both eyes)
    • Memory impairment (if it affects the hippocampus)
    • Alexia without agraphia (an inability to read without an inability to write) if the dominant hemisphere is involved.

 

Option B) Middle cerebral artery (MCA).

 

  • It supplies blood to the majority of the outer convex brain surface, including the frontal, parietal, and superior temporal lobes.
  • Thrombosis of the MCA can lead to:
    • Contralateral hemiparesis and sensory loss (mainly of the face and upper limb)
    • If the dominant hemisphere (typically the left in right-handed individuals) is affected, expressive aphasia can occur.
    • If the non-dominant hemisphere is involved, spatial neglect might be observed.

 

Option C) Internal carotid artery (ICA).

 

  • It does not give off any significant branches in its cervical or petrous portions. Its terminal branches in the brain are the MCA and ACA (anterior cerebral artery).
  • Thrombosis of the ICA can compromise blood flow to both the ACA and MCA territories, leading to a combination of the symptoms associated with obstruction of those arteries.

 

Option D) Superior cerebellar artery (SCA).

 

  • It supplies blood to the superior part of the cerebellum and parts of the midbrain.
  • Thrombosis of the SCA can result in:
    • Ataxia, which is uncoordinated and clumsy movements due to the involvement of the cerebellum.
    • Dysmetria, which is a lack of coordination between intended and actual movements, causing overshooting or undershooting of the target.
    • Tremors and other cerebellar signs

choices.text: Surface tension – decreased; Compliance – increased
Surface tension – increased; Compliance – decreased
Both surface tension and compliance decreased
Both surface tension and compliance increased

questions.text: A preterm baby, who was delivered at 28 weeks, developed respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following is true about surface tension and compliance in this baby?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surface tension – increased; Compliance – decreased

 

  • This preterm baby who developed respiratory distress syndrome has surfactant deficiency. Due to which surface tension increases and compliance decreases.
  • Surfactant (Lecithin/Dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl Choline) is produced by specialized cells called type II alveolar cells in the lungs.
  • Surfactant molecules have a hydrophilic (water-attracting) head and a hydrophobic (water-repellent) tail.
  • This unique structure allows surfactant to lower the surface tension at the air-liquid interface of the alveoli.
  • It reduces the attractive forces between water molecules, preventing the alveoli from collapsing during expiration.
  • Compliance refers to the ability of the lungs to expand and recoil efficiently during breathing.
  • Without surfactant, the surface tension within the alveoli would be high, making it difficult for the lungs to inflate during inspiration and causing them to collapse more readily during expiration.

questions.text: Which of following color reaction yields a positive result for an amino acid which can be synthesized from phenylalanine in our body and characterized by an aromatic side chain?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Millon’s test

 

  • The aromatic amino acid mentioned in this question is tyrosine which can be formed by enzyme Phenylalaine hydroxylase from amino acid phenylalaine.
  • In Millon’s reaction, the phenol group of phenylalanine and tyrosine containing proteins, when heated with mercuric sulfate in sulphuric acid and sodium nitrite form red coloured mercury phenolate.

 

 

  • Done by Millon, 1812-1867.
  • Chloride interferes with this reaction.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Sakaguchi’s test. Test for Arginine.

 

Option C) Ninhydrin test. General test for all alpha amino acids.

 

Option D) Biuret test. General test for proteins.

 

Ref: Vasudevan, 9th edition, page no. 31

questions.text: A patient with diabetes and COPD developed post-operative urinary retention. Which of the following drugs can be used for short-term treatment of the condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bethanechol

 

  • Alpha blockers like Terazosin and Tamsulosin are used for treatment of urinary symptoms in BPH. These have no role in treatment of post-operative urinary retention.
  • Bethanechol is muscarinic agonist that used in the treatment of post-operative urinary retention.
  • It can lead to bronchoconstriction by its action over M3 receptors in the bronchus.
  • Therefore, it should be avoided in patients with bronchial asthma and COPD.
  • Methacholine is a muscarinic receptor agonist that can precipitate bronchoconstriction and is used in the diagnosis of asthma by performing the bronchial challenge test.
  • So, among the given options, the best answer seems to be bethanechol.
  • The reason is that, although it can worsen bronchoconstriction in patients with COPD, but it is the only drug among the options that can be used for treatment of post-operative urinary retention.
  • Other drugs have no role in treatment of post-operative urinary retention and hence, cannot be the answer.

choices.text: Relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter
Increased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus
Increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the pathology of achalasia cardia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter 

 

  • Achalasia cardia is characterized by decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus.
  • The LES relaxes during swallowing due to the release of nitric oxide and vasoactive intestinal polypeptide from inhibitory neurons, as well as the interruption of normal cholinergic signaling. These inhibitory neurons degenerate in achalasia cardia, resulting in decreased NO and VIP release. This results in increased LES tone.
  • The triad of achalasia cardia is as follows:
    • Incomplete relaxation of LES
    • Increased tone of LES
    • Absent peristalsis (aperistalsis)

questions.text: Viral infection mimicking erythroblastosis fetalis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Parvovirus B19

 

  • Parvovirus B19 infection mimics erythroblastosis fetalis.
  • Parvovirus B19 is associated with:
  • Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease)
    1. Transient aplastic crisis
    2. Pure red cell aplasia
    3. Erythroblastosis fetalis (most commonly in early pregnancy)
    4. Picornavirus, Epstein-Barr virus, HV infection do not mimic erythroblastosis fetalis.
  • Erythema infectiosum rash:

choices.text: Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy.
It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection.
Bilateral orchidectomy is generally performed.
Compulsory urinary diversion is performed.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient visits the emergency department due to rapidly worsening pain and swelling in the genital and perianal regions, with signs of necrotizing infection as shown below upon examination. The patient has a history of alcohol abuse and poorly controlled diabetes, and laboratory tests reveal leukocytosis and elevated blood glucose levels. What is the accurate statement about the condition presented by the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection

 

  • The image provided suggests Fournier's gangrene, which is a mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection and a surgical emergency.
  • Fournier's gangrene is a rapidly progressive infection of the genitalia and perineum caused by mixed bacterial flora, often associated with diabetes, cancer, malnutrition, recent urogenital or colorectal instrumentation, or trauma.
  • Symptoms of Fournier's gangrene include erythema, swelling, pain, and blister formation with ultimately foul-smelling necrotic lesions.
  • Fournier's gangrene involves a mixed infection with both aerobic (oxygen-using) and anaerobic (not oxygen-using) bacteria.
  • The presence of multiple bacterial types contributes to the rapid progression and severity of the disease.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy. Incorrect. Anti-gas gangrene serum therapy is typically used for the treatment of gas gangrene caused by the bacterium Clostridium perfringens. While C. perfringens can sometimes be a part of the mixed bacterial flora in Fournier's gangrene, the condition itself is not specifically gas gangrene, and thus anti-gas gangrene serum therapy is not the primary treatment.

 

Option C) Bilateral orchidectomy is generally performed. Incorrect. A bilateral orchidectomy, or the removal of both testes, is not a standard treatment for Fournier's gangrene. Testes are typically spared in Fournier’s gangrene.

 

Option D) Compulsory urinary diversion is performed. Incorrect. While urinary diversion might be considered in some cases where the urethra is compromised or if there's significant involvement of the urogenital structures, it's not a compulsory or routine part of the management of Fournier's gangrene.

questions.text: Identify the type of hymen shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Septate hymen

 

  • The given image is suggestive of the septate hymen.
  • The hymen is the membranous vestige of the junction between the sino-vaginal bulbs and the urogenital sinus, which perforates during fetal life to establish a connection between the vaginal lumen and the perineum.
  • Defective perforation of this structure may result in the following variants of hymen:
    • Imperforate: without any opening (presents as cryptomenorrhea at puberty)
    • Micro-perforate: tiny opening
    • Annular: oval central opening
    • Septate: two lateral openings partitioned by a bridge of hymenal tissue (may have difficulty in intercourse, placement of a tampon)
    • Naviculate: boat-like opening

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Different types of hymen:

 

 

Ref: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition, Page no. 18
